I reckon the Catholic Church could use some tweaking in a few ways, you know?
They've been chatting about their dwindling flock, and I think it's because they're not too accepting, you see?
Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control—these are just a few examples.
They've got strong views, no doubt, but they're a bit antiquated, if you get my drift.
I think if they embraced a more contemporary outlook, they wouldn't be so worried about losing their followers.
I've heard of folks distancing themselves from the Church due to their stance on these issues.
People aren't aligning with their views on certain matters these days.
So I guess they think the Church is a bit off on these topics.
I mean, the Church's anti-abortion stance might make some uncomfortable, especially if they believe in it.
And the same goes for gay marriage—if you feel strongly about it, you might not want to follow a church that's against it.
I don't see why they can't have female priests or let priests get married, but then again, I'm not sure if that would've changed what happened.
I mean, it's hard to say what they'd do differently if they could marry or have women priests.
But I'm not convinced it would've made a significant difference.
I just don't get why priests can't have a family life like everyone else.
They say they're married to God, but everyone else has both work and family life, so why can't they?

Well, I'm not against gay marriage, you know. I mean, who am I to judge? Whether someone is born that way, or whatever, I don't think it's something people choose. So, I think it's unfair to hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can marry, but not two people of the same sex. That's wrong, in my opinion. I haven't really given the topic much thought, but I'd say that's just not right. It's not a choice, like they don't have a say in how they are. I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It doesn't seem like a conscious decision they should be held accountable for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, or even a moral one. It's not about our country's security or anything like that. It's just that they're out of place when they try to interject in people's lives. And that's just who they are. It's like their birthright, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all I have to say about that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Why? Well, let me put it simply, there's no compelling reason not to. Some people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional heterosexual families, but it's just not that straightforward. Truth be told, there are so many different aspects to this issue that it's foolish to compare it to anything else. It's like two sides of the same coin, no matter how much you try to flip it, they're still the same face. It's not like one is heads and the other tails, they're just different sides of the same reality. And there are so many civil rights implications at play here, like property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be by your side in your time of need, because they're not technically family. I mean, if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone, it seems silly to deny them that right. Plus, scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates as heterosexual couples in terms of relationship satisfaction. It's just a relationship, plain and simple. And let's not forget, the people who want to get married aren't asking for the religious sanctification of their union. They just want a legal document that recognizes their commitment, a marriage certificate. If there's no religious involvement, then how can that be an issue? I can't comprehend why people like Catholics would object to this based on their religious beliefs, especially when they're not even directly involved. If you're allowing civil unions, then why not allow marriage? It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal. Homosexual relationships are no different in terms of community involvement or parenting skills. Children of gay couples are just as well-adjusted as children of heterosexual couples. And the federal government should be at the forefront of this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state. But, of course, President Bush has his own strong views on this matter, much like his stance on abortion and stem cell research. He seems to be driven by moral reasons, but morality is subjective and varies from person to person. The government should not enforce the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. It's hypocritical to let laws be made that enforce religious standards on everyone, especially considering the recent controversies about the pledge of allegiance. Many people are opposed to gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but that's just not accurate. The American Psychological Association has stated this is untrue. If only people listened to institutions that do actual research instead of relying on popular opinion or their local community's beliefs.

Now, let me start by saying that I happen to be working at a hospital pharmacy this summer. And while it's true that not all illegal drugs are beneficial, there's a certain irony in that. You see, the very fact that something is illegal doesn't mean it lacks use, especially in the medical field. I'm talking about opioids like oxycodone, vicodin, percocets—you name it. They're controlled substances because they have their benefits, yet we use them all the time. And the thing about marijuana, well, it's not the same as alcohol. While both can be abused, marijuana, when used responsibly, is a different beast. I believe you could gradually make it legal, but first, you've got to remove that taboo around marijuana. Too many people have a skewed image of it, thinking it's as harmful as heroin or cocaine. But I'm telling you, it's not. If we can get past that image, people might start using it responsibly, and certainly for medicinal purposes. But right now, with that stigma? It's a no-go.

So, I'm of the opinion that the church has subtly adapted to the 21st century, but it ain't as rigid as it used to be. Growing up, it was all about Sunday mass, with cute little dresses, matching shoes, and purses. I'd see most of my private school friends there on weekends. But now, it's different. They've introduced a 'teenage mass,' cutting it down to 30 minutes, and people dress more casually, even in their beachwear. Families are coming in late, and at morning masses, you see folks in jeans and khakis. It's more relaxed, but I'm not aware of the church's politics, so that's all I've got. As for the accusations against Catholic priests, I think it's a matter of individual choice and genetics. Marriage, for them or any other faith, wouldn't change that. The problem's in the genes, not in the church's rules or lack thereof. The church could've done more to address this, but I don't think it's entirely their fault.

Initially, I was okay with the whole thing, but it seems everyone was still reeling from the September 11th attacks, and we seem to have entered Iraq as a pretext. There were several pretexts that led us into Iraq. Early on, the Bush administration connected the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, all of which has since proven false.
And that really grinds my gears. It just seems like the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, coming back from his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it.
To me, that's just malfeasance in office. I think that's an impeachable offense. They lied to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the Constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since, well, since September 11th at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

Alright, let me see, I'm really for gay marriage. Always have been. It's a personal preference, and it's something that's been proven to be more biological than sociological. So, denying people rights based on something they have no control over seems kind of inhumane to me. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage.

I don't think politics or government should have a say in this. It's not even something that should be on a state level; it's a personal, household level. My neighborhood, for instance, has two or three openly gay couples living there, not married because they're not allowed to. But they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs down the street like anyone else. And with Bush trying to play God and interpret marriage the way he wants, it's just ridiculous.

I mean, I think it's something that's been proven to be a biological predisposition. I've read and heard from numerous publications that it's something you might be predisposed to being a homosexual, not something that's solely sociological. Like growing up with lots of sisters and a single father could influence it, but it's not the only factor.

But other than the obvious, I think maybe it's because marriage is something that, if a guy and a girl want to do it, they can just run off to Las Vegas and do it without telling anyone. But if two gay people want to do it, it's going to make the front page of the New York Times. I think it should be a personal, private thing, not something in the public domain or national and federal domain.

Listen, putting stuff online is public. People can see it, and it can color their opinions of you. If you're talking about harmful stuff, like wanting to blow something up or shoot someone, someone's gonna notice. The internet is a huge public forum, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. The school isn't the one who got the warning, someone else did. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have prevented it. But sometimes, people just mess around, and you don't know what to take seriously. Like that time at school; something happened, and someone overheard someone else saying something, then called it in. When they found out who said it, they checked their Facebook, and it turned out they were just joking. But in that situation, it became serious. When you put something out there, it's not private. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control what people think or take seriously. I don't think school officials should friend their students on social media and snoop around. But if it's brought to their attention, there's no privacy issue because it's something they were given access to. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I don't think teachers should make fake accounts to friend students. That's not appropriate. I wouldn't want to see my residents' wild nights out on Facebook, not because I care, but because it's not my business. It's not my place to know or to act on it. I respect their privacy, and I don't need that connection.

Um, I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in another country. But I think we've lost sight of that original goal. Now, it's just about proving our global dominance, and maybe even settling old scores. George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein might have played a role. If the original intent was to give a fair political system to a country under a tyrant, it was a just cause. But over time, I think our objectives have become murky, like we're still at war just to prove we can be at war. We're not ready to admit defeat, and we're spending billions of dollars on a war that's gone on too long. We've been neglecting our own economy, our own citizens' well-being, and it's not sustainable. I mean, they're spending billions and billions, and there are more pressing issues at home, like poverty and infrastructure, that we should be funding instead. Right now, that money is being spent on a war that's lost its cause. I think it's time to step back and let the locals handle it.

Right. On platforms like Myspace, if you post information, it's pretty much available to anyone. You have to have a friend's permission to see someone's profile, but that's their choice. If they've accepted you as a friend, you're giving them permission to see what you're sharing.

I mean, anytime you put information on the internet, you're essentially opening yourself up to a wider audience. And if I'm being honest, I think that's a bit unnerving.

It's tough, you know? You can't realistically have one person watching everyone's profiles all day to prevent something like this. But then again, if it's a case of the school or authorities looking at certain profiles, that could be a bit unfair. It could feel like they're singling out specific students.

I don't know, though. It depends on the situation. Maybe they were looking for evidence of something, or maybe they were just randomly browsing and happened to stumble upon something.

I mean, I don't have a Myspace myself, but I do have a Facebook. It bothers me that there are people out there who can find out a lot about me just by looking at my profile. I've seen something on TV where a guy was able to find a girl's screen name and talk to her on instant messenger in just a few minutes. That's a bit scary.

I don't think I'd meet up with someone like that, but I've had people in my classes who I don't recognize but they know who I am from my IM. It's hard because I have to think about my interests, my schedule, even who I'm friends with. It's a tricky balance, you know? I only accept people I know as friends, but you never know who might be looking.

My roommate told me that in high school, some schools actually banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit strange to me. I'm not sure how they had the power to do that.

I don't really know if that's a privacy issue, but I don't think they had the right to tell people they couldn't have Myspace.

You see, they didn’t legalize it, no, not by a long shot. They decriminalized it, yeah. That means they knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—you know, get cited and be on your way, rather than getting booked, arrested, and dragged into court. And sure, if you get caught, it may show up on your record, affecting job prospects and such. But you know, the stigma of a drug charge looms large, even if it's just weed. Decriminalization doesn't erase that.

Imagine the cost, though. Arresting, booking, and processing people, not to mention the trials, public defenders, judges, and court fees. It adds up to a hefty bill for the state. In places strapped for cash, they just can't afford to make that concession, even if it might free up some money for other needs. But in a place like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, it's a different story. Decriminalizing it could mean more funds for public education and social programs.

Now, I’m not saying we should make it legal to walk around smoking it everywhere. That would be a whole different kettle of fish. It's still taboo in many places, and the thought of seeing people openly smoking weed on the streets might be uncomfortable for some. And then there's the issue of lifestyle impact. Sure, alcohol can mess with your driving skills, but marijuana often affects people's lifestyle more than just their decision-making abilities.

Every person reacts differently, you know? Some can handle anything, others know how to moderate, and some just can't. So, it's hard to generalize about how these substances affect people. But make no mistake, they all have their adverse effects.

It might not change much.

I'm still undecided about the nuptial union debate. See, it's a delicate dance, balancing the separation of church and state with the sanctity of marriage.   I mean, if the government can't distinguish between a holy union and a civil one, then why should we let them dictate how we define love?   So, if two people are legally bound, shouldn't we just call it a civil union?   It's a union of two individuals, no more, no less.   And if all states can reach a sensible consensus, then let's push for federal recognition, but a constitutional ban on gay marriage? That's as absurd as amending our founding document for a fling.   It just doesn't warrant such a grand gesture.   So, no. I'm not convinced.

I was actually raised in a Christian home, so like, homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. Because I have a lot of gay friends, I think that I don’t necessarily agree with that lifestyle. But I think that it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue. However, I feel as though it should be something that each state decides on their own, rather than the president deciding for the entire country.

Well, like a lot of states are democratic, and a lot of states are republican. Obviously, democratic states are gonna push for gay marriage, and if you’re living in a democratic state, like, obviously you know how that state feels about that position. And I don’t think that you’re necessarily in a place to disagree with that decision if a state does decide to legalize gay marriage, because you kind of chose to live there. So I think I don’t think homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals so I feel as though it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

Well, I kind of already answered that. But yeah, I don’t feel as though Bush should be allowed to decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think that it should be up to the individual states as to whether they want to legalize it. I don’t agree with his ban on it.

I just don’t think like, I don’t think that Bush doesn’t live in every single state, so he shouldn’t be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. I guess I don’t know. So, I think that some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he’s gonna be out of office in like what two years, and if a democratic president decides that he wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, like, it’s just going to go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they’re the ones that are gonna have to live with that decision. Not the president.

Hmm, I gotta say, I don't buy that. Let me break it down for you. You see, Myspace is meant for public consumption, right? It's like a digital bulletin board for everyone to see, whether it's your peers or not. If school officials want to check up on what students are up to, they've got every right to do so, especially if it's for the greater good. Now, I'm not saying they should go snooping for no reason, but if they find something that could save lives or make the school safer, I think they should be allowed to do their job. It's a responsibility of the school system to keep students safe. I mean, if they find out about students partying or doing drugs, that's their job, right? They're there to keep us safe, not to spy on us. But if it helps make the school a better place, then I'm all for it. The same goes for the police. Parents send their kids to school expecting a safe environment. Sure, we do drills and practice for lockdowns. That's part of making the school safer. So, if school officials are doing the same, I think they're just trying to keep us safe. They're not invading our privacy, they're just doing their job.

Right
Yeah
The war
Yeah
At first, I was all in. I was deeply affected by the World Trade Center attacks, and I was ready to unleash hell over there.
But looking back, I think we let our emotions cloud our judgment. We didn't think about the long-term consequences and just went in unprepared. We were like a bull in a china shop, causing more chaos than it was worth.
I’ve since changed my stance. I don't believe our presence there has made any real difference. They’re so caught up in their own conflicts, they can’t focus on us. It's like we’re just a distraction.
I've lost all interest in what happens over there. I mean, they’re just fighting amongst themselves, so why should we care? They can’t even get along with themselves.
We just went in there with our emotions high and no real plan. We were driven by anger and revenge, more than anything else. We should have been more rational about what we were getting into. We couldn’t have just allowed them to get away with what they did.
I still think we had no choice but to go to war, but we should have been better prepared. We had no clear plan, no unity of purpose. We just went in with emotions, and that’s what we ended up creating.
I really don’t think we’re the ones to change those people. They’re always going to be like that, and I don’t think we’re making enough progress to justify our stay.
We need to consider leaving, and we need to do it soon. We can’t stay over there forever. It’s hurting us more than it’s helping.
So, that’s where I stand.

I reckon the Catholic Church could use some tweaking in a few ways, you know?
They've been chatting about their dwindling flock, and I think it's because they're not too accepting, you see?
Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control—these are just a few examples.
They've got strong views, no doubt, but they're a bit antiquated, if you get my drift.
I think if they embraced a more contemporary outlook, they wouldn't be so worried about losing their followers.
I've heard of folks distancing themselves from the Church due to their stance on these issues.
People aren't aligning with their views on certain matters these days.
So I guess they think the Church is a bit off on these topics.
I mean, the Church's anti-abortion stance might make some uncomfortable, especially if they believe in it.
And the same goes for gay marriage—if you feel strongly about it, you might not want to follow a church that's against it.
I don't see why they can't have female priests or let priests get married, but then again, I'm not sure if that would've changed what happened.
I mean, it's hard to say what they'd do differently if they could marry or have women priests.
But I'm not convinced it would've made a significant difference.
I just don't get why priests can't have a family life like everyone else.
They say they're married to God, but everyone else has both work and family life, so why can't they?

Well, I'm not against gay marriage, you know. I mean, who am I to judge? Whether someone is born that way, or whatever, I don't think it's something people choose. So, I think it's unfair to hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can marry, but not two people of the same sex. That's wrong, in my opinion. I haven't really given the topic much thought, but I'd say that's just not right. It's not a choice, like they don't have a say in how they are. I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It doesn't seem like a conscious decision they should be held accountable for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, or even a moral one. It's not about our country's security or anything like that. It's just that they're out of place when they try to interject in people's lives. And that's just who they are. It's like their birthright, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all I have to say about that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Why? Well, let me put it simply, there's no compelling reason not to. Some people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional heterosexual families, but it's just not that straightforward. Truth be told, there are so many different aspects to this issue that it's foolish to compare it to anything else. It's like two sides of the same coin, no matter how much you try to flip it, they're still the same face. It's not like one is heads and the other tails, they're just different sides of the same reality. And there are so many civil rights implications at play here, like property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be by your side in your time of need, because they're not technically family. I mean, if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone, it seems silly to deny them that right. Plus, scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates as heterosexual couples in terms of relationship satisfaction. It's just a relationship, plain and simple. And let's not forget, the people who want to get married aren't asking for the religious sanctification of their union. They just want a legal document that recognizes their commitment, a marriage certificate. If there's no religious involvement, then how can that be an issue? I can't comprehend why people like Catholics would object to this based on their religious beliefs, especially when they're not even directly involved. If you're allowing civil unions, then why not allow marriage? It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal. Homosexual relationships are no different in terms of community involvement or parenting skills. Children of gay couples are just as well-adjusted as children of heterosexual couples. And the federal government should be at the forefront of this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state. But, of course, President Bush has his own strong views on this matter, much like his stance on abortion and stem cell research. He seems to be driven by moral reasons, but morality is subjective and varies from person to person. The government should not enforce the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. It's hypocritical to let laws be made that enforce religious standards on everyone, especially considering the recent controversies about the pledge of allegiance. Many people are opposed to gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but that's just not accurate. The American Psychological Association has stated this is untrue. If only people listened to institutions that do actual research instead of relying on popular opinion or their local community's beliefs.

Now, let me start by saying that I happen to be working at a hospital pharmacy this summer. And while it's true that not all illegal drugs are beneficial, there's a certain irony in that. You see, the very fact that something is illegal doesn't mean it lacks use, especially in the medical field. I'm talking about opioids like oxycodone, vicodin, percocets—you name it. They're controlled substances because they have their benefits, yet we use them all the time. And the thing about marijuana, well, it's not the same as alcohol. While both can be abused, marijuana, when used responsibly, is a different beast. I believe you could gradually make it legal, but first, you've got to remove that taboo around marijuana. Too many people have a skewed image of it, thinking it's as harmful as heroin or cocaine. But I'm telling you, it's not. If we can get past that image, people might start using it responsibly, and certainly for medicinal purposes. But right now, with that stigma? It's a no-go.

So, I'm of the opinion that the church has subtly adapted to the 21st century, but it ain't as rigid as it used to be. Growing up, it was all about Sunday mass, with cute little dresses, matching shoes, and purses. I'd see most of my private school friends there on weekends. But now, it's different. They've introduced a 'teenage mass,' cutting it down to 30 minutes, and people dress more casually, even in their beachwear. Families are coming in late, and at morning masses, you see folks in jeans and khakis. It's more relaxed, but I'm not aware of the church's politics, so that's all I've got. As for the accusations against Catholic priests, I think it's a matter of individual choice and genetics. Marriage, for them or any other faith, wouldn't change that. The problem's in the genes, not in the church's rules or lack thereof. The church could've done more to address this, but I don't think it's entirely their fault.

And that really grinds my gears. It just seems like the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, coming back from his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it.
To me, that's just malfeasance in office. I think that's an impeachable offense. They lied to the American people like that. The war in Iraq

Before invading Iraq, I think there was an attempt to tie the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which really didn’t have much to do with each other
But the government played on the emotions of the American people, using their outrage against the 9/11 attacks to justify the invasion, which began in 2003
I myself am against war, especially making a preemptive strike. I was against that
Um
And I think that the war in Iraq is kind of a repeat of the Vietnam War
The government should have learned from past mistakes
A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died
And I don’t think the American government was prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that would follow removing the Iraqi government
Um
And the United States is trying to implant a democratic government, similar to what happened in Vietnam

And trying to train Iraqi troops and police forces

I mean, democracy takes years to implement and become successful
And I think the government made it seem like an easy thing to do

Alright, let me see, I'm really for gay marriage. Always have been. It's a personal preference, and it's something that's been proven to be more biological than sociological. So, denying people rights based on something they have no control over seems kind of inhumane to me. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage.

I don't think politics or government should have a say in this. It's not even something that should be on a state level; it's a personal, household level. My neighborhood, for instance, has two or three openly gay couples living there, not married because they're not allowed to. But they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs down the street like anyone else. And with Bush trying to play God and interpret marriage the way he wants, it's just ridiculous.

I mean, I think it's something that's been proven to be a biological predisposition. I've read and heard from numerous publications that it's something you might be predisposed to being a homosexual, not something that's solely sociological. Like growing up with lots of sisters and a single father could influence it, but it's not the only factor.

But other than the obvious, I think maybe it's because marriage is something that, if a guy and a girl want to do it, they can just run off to Las Vegas and do it without telling anyone. But if two gay people want to do it, it's going to make the front page of the New York Times. I think it should be a personal, private thing, not something in the public domain or national and federal domain.

No, no.

Listen, putting stuff online is public. People can see it, and it can color their opinions of you. If you're talking about harmful stuff, like wanting to blow something up or shoot someone, someone's gonna notice. The internet is a huge public forum, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. The school isn't the one who got the warning, someone else did. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have prevented it. But sometimes, people just mess around, and you don't know what to take seriously. Like that time at school; something happened, and someone overheard someone else saying something, then called it in. When they found out who said it, they checked their Facebook, and it turned out they were just joking. But in that situation, it became serious. When you put something out there, it's not private. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control what people think or take seriously. I don't think school officials should friend their students on social media and snoop around. But if it's brought to their attention, there's no privacy issue because it's something they were given access to. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I don't think teachers should make fake accounts to friend students. That's not appropriate. I wouldn't want to see my residents' wild nights out on Facebook, not because I care, but because it's not my business. It's not my place to know or to act on it. I respect their privacy, and I don't need that connection.

Um, I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in another country. But I think we've lost sight of that original goal. Now, it's just about proving our global dominance, and maybe even settling old scores. George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein might have played a role. If the original intent was to give a fair political system to a country under a tyrant, it was a just cause. But over time, I think our objectives have become murky, like we're still at war just to prove we can be at war. We're not ready to admit defeat, and we're spending billions of dollars on a war that's gone on too long. We've been neglecting our own economy, our own citizens' well-being, and it's not sustainable. I mean, they're spending billions and billions, and there are more pressing issues at home, like poverty and infrastructure, that we should be funding instead. Right now, that money is being spent on a war that's lost its cause. I think it's time to step back and let the locals handle it.

Can I clarify something? You know, I've heard that someone went online and found something that... well, it's hard to put into words.

Okay, so just to make sure I understand, you're saying that what happened wasn't an invasion of privacy?

Right. On platforms like Myspace, if you post information, it's pretty much available to anyone. You have to have a friend's permission to see someone's profile, but that's their choice. If they've accepted you as a friend, you're giving them permission to see what you're sharing.

I mean, anytime you put information on the internet, you're essentially opening yourself up to a wider audience. And if I'm being honest, I think that's a bit unnerving.

It's tough, you know? You can't realistically have one person watching everyone's profiles all day to prevent something like this. But then again, if it's a case of the school or authorities looking at certain profiles, that could be a bit unfair. It could feel like they're singling out specific students.

I don't know, though. It depends on the situation. Maybe they were looking for evidence of something, or maybe they were just randomly browsing and happened to stumble upon something.

I mean, I don't have a Myspace myself, but I do have a Facebook. It bothers me that there are people out there who can find out a lot about me just by looking at my profile. I've seen something on TV where a guy was able to find a girl's screen name and talk to her on instant messenger in just a few minutes. That's a bit scary.

I don't think I'd meet up with someone like that, but I've had people in my classes who I don't recognize but they know who I am from my IM. It's hard because I have to think about my interests, my schedule, even who I'm friends with. It's a tricky balance, you know? I only accept people I know as friends, but you never know who might be looking.

My roommate told me that in high school, some schools actually banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit strange to me. I'm not sure how they had the power to do that.

I don't really know if that's a privacy issue, but I don't think they had the right to tell people they couldn't have Myspace.

You see, they didn’t legalize it, no, not by a long shot. They decriminalized it, yeah. That means they knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—you know, get cited and be on your way, rather than getting booked, arrested, and dragged into court. And sure, if you get caught, it may show up on your record, affecting job prospects and such. But you know, the stigma of a drug charge looms large, even if it's just weed. Decriminalization doesn't erase that.

Imagine the cost, though. Arresting, booking, and processing people, not to mention the trials, public defenders, judges, and court fees. It adds up to a hefty bill for the state. In places strapped for cash, they just can't afford to make that concession, even if it might free up some money for other needs. But in a place like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, it's a different story. Decriminalizing it could mean more funds for public education and social programs.

Now, I’m not saying we should make it legal to walk around smoking it everywhere. That would be a whole different kettle of fish. It's still taboo in many places, and the thought of seeing people openly smoking weed on the streets might be uncomfortable for some. And then there's the issue of lifestyle impact. Sure, alcohol can mess with your driving skills, but marijuana often affects people's lifestyle more than just their decision-making abilities.

Every person reacts differently, you know? Some can handle anything, others know how to moderate, and some just can't. So, it's hard to generalize about how these substances affect people. But make no mistake, they all have their adverse effects.

Well, child molesters are likely to act that way regardless of their marital status,
It's about the power dynamic, not the spouse.
So, I don't think marrying priests would stop those acts.
It might not change much.

I'm still undecided about the nuptial union debate. See, it's a delicate dance, balancing the separation of church and state with the sanctity of marriage.   I mean, if the government can't distinguish between a holy union and a civil one, then why should we let them dictate how we define love?   So, if two people are legally bound, shouldn't we just call it a civil union?   It's a union of two individuals, no more, no less.   And if all states can reach a sensible consensus, then let's push for federal recognition, but a constitutional ban on gay marriage? That's as absurd as amending our founding document for a fling.   It just doesn't warrant such a grand gesture.   So, no. I'm not convinced.

I was actually raised in a Christian home, so like, homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. Because I have a lot of gay friends, I think that I don’t necessarily agree with that lifestyle. But I think that it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue. However, I feel as though it should be something that each state decides on their own, rather than the president deciding for the entire country.

Well, like a lot of states are democratic, and a lot of states are republican. Obviously, democratic states are gonna push for gay marriage, and if you’re living in a democratic state, like, obviously you know how that state feels about that position. And I don’t think that you’re necessarily in a place to disagree with that decision if a state does decide to legalize gay marriage, because you kind of chose to live there. So I think I don’t think homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals so I feel as though it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

Well, I kind of already answered that. But yeah, I don’t feel as though Bush should be allowed to decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think that it should be up to the individual states as to whether they want to legalize it. I don’t agree with his ban on it.

I just don’t think like, I don’t think that Bush doesn’t live in every single state, so he shouldn’t be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. I guess I don’t know. So, I think that some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he’s gonna be out of office in like what two years, and if a democratic president decides that he wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, like, it’s just going to go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they’re the ones that are gonna have to live with that decision. Not the president.

No, I don’t

Hmm, I gotta say, I don't buy that. Let me break it down for you. You see, Myspace is meant for public consumption, right? It's like a digital bulletin board for everyone to see, whether it's your peers or not. If school officials want to check up on what students are up to, they've got every right to do so, especially if it's for the greater good. Now, I'm not saying they should go snooping for no reason, but if they find something that could save lives or make the school safer, I think they should be allowed to do their job. It's a responsibility of the school system to keep students safe. I mean, if they find out about students partying or doing drugs, that's their job, right? They're there to keep us safe, not to spy on us. But if it helps make the school a better place, then I'm all for it. The same goes for the police. Parents send their kids to school expecting a safe environment. Sure, we do drills and practice for lockdowns. That's part of making the school safer. So, if school officials are doing the same, I think they're just trying to keep us safe. They're not invading our privacy, they're just doing their job.

Right
Yeah
The war
Yeah
At first, I was all in. I was deeply affected by the World Trade Center attacks, and I was ready to unleash hell over there.
But looking back, I think we let our emotions cloud our judgment. We didn't think about the long-term consequences and just went in unprepared. We were like a bull in a china shop, causing more chaos than it was worth.
I’ve since changed my stance. I don't believe our presence there has made any real difference. They’re so caught up in their own conflicts, they can’t focus on us. It's like we’re just a distraction.
I've lost all interest in what happens over there. I mean, they’re just fighting amongst themselves, so why should we care? They can’t even get along with themselves.
We just went in there with our emotions high and no real plan. We were driven by anger and revenge, more than anything else. We should have been more rational about what we were getting into. We couldn’t have just allowed them to get away with what they did.
I still think we had no choice but to go to war, but we should have been better prepared. We had no clear plan, no unity of purpose. We just went in with emotions, and that’s what we ended up creating.
I really don’t think we’re the ones to change those people. They’re always going to be like that, and I don’t think we’re making enough progress to justify our stay.
We need to consider leaving, and we need to do it soon. We can’t stay over there forever. It’s hurting us more than it’s helping.
So, that’s where I stand.

transformed_texts:
I reckon the Catholic Church could use some tweaking in a few ways, you know?
They've been chatting about their dwindling flock, and I think it's because they're not too accepting, you see?
Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control—these are just a few examples.
They've got strong views, no doubt, but they're a bit antiquated, if you get my drift.
I think if they embraced a more contemporary outlook, they wouldn't be so worried about losing their followers.
I've heard of folks distancing themselves from the Church due to their stance on these issues.
People aren't aligning with their views on certain matters these days.
So I guess they think the Church is a bit off on these topics.
I mean, the Church's anti-abortion stance might make some uncomfortable, especially if they believe in it.
And the same goes for gay marriage—if you feel strongly about it, you might not want to follow a church that's against it.
I don't see why they can't have female priests or let priests get married, but then again, I'm not sure if that would've changed what happened.
I mean, it's hard to say what they'd do differently if they could marry or have women priests.
But I'm not convinced it would've made a significant difference.
I just don't get why priests can't have a family life like everyone else.
They say they're married to God, but everyone else has both work and family life, so why can't they?

Well, I'm not against gay marriage, you know. I mean, who am I to judge? Whether someone is born that way, or whatever, I don't think it's something people choose. So, I think it's unfair to hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can marry, but not two people of the same sex. That's wrong, in my opinion. I haven't really given the topic much thought, but I'd say that's just not right. It's not a choice, like they don't have a say in how they are. I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It doesn't seem like a conscious decision they should be held accountable for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, or even a moral one. It's not about our country's security or anything like that. It's just that they're out of place when they try to interject in people's lives. And that's just who they are. It's like their birthright, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all I have to say about that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Why? Well, let me put it simply, there's no compelling reason not to. Some people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional heterosexual families, but it's just not that straightforward. Truth be told, there are so many different aspects to this issue that it's foolish to compare it to anything else. It's like two sides of the same coin, no matter how much you try to flip it, they're still the same face. It's not like one is heads and the other tails, they're just different sides of the same reality. And there are so many civil rights implications at play here, like property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be by your side in your time of need, because they're not technically family. I mean, if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone, it seems silly to deny them that right. Plus, scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates as heterosexual couples in terms of relationship satisfaction. It's just a relationship, plain and simple. And let's not forget, the people who want to get married aren't asking for the religious sanctification of their union. They just want a legal document that recognizes their commitment, a marriage certificate. If there's no religious involvement, then how can that be an issue? I can't comprehend why people like Catholics would object to this based on their religious beliefs, especially when they're not even directly involved. If you're allowing civil unions, then why not allow marriage? It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal. Homosexual relationships are no different in terms of community involvement or parenting skills. Children of gay couples are just as well-adjusted as children of heterosexual couples. And the federal government should be at the forefront of this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state. But, of course, President Bush has his own strong views on this matter, much like his stance on abortion and stem cell research. He seems to be driven by moral reasons, but morality is subjective and varies from person to person. The government should not enforce the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. It's hypocritical to let laws be made that enforce religious standards on everyone, especially considering the recent controversies about the pledge of allegiance. Many people are opposed to gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but that's just not accurate. The American Psychological Association has stated this is untrue. If only people listened to institutions that do actual research instead of relying on popular opinion or their local community's beliefs.

Now, let me start by saying that I happen to be working at a hospital pharmacy this summer. And while it's true that not all illegal drugs are beneficial, there's a certain irony in that. You see, the very fact that something is illegal doesn't mean it lacks use, especially in the medical field. I'm talking about opioids like oxycodone, vicodin, percocets—you name it. They're controlled substances because they have their benefits, yet we use them all the time. And the thing about marijuana, well, it's not the same as alcohol. While both can be abused, marijuana, when used responsibly, is a different beast. I believe you could gradually make it legal, but first, you've got to remove that taboo around marijuana. Too many people have a skewed image of it, thinking it's as harmful as heroin or cocaine. But I'm telling you, it's not. If we can get past that image, people might start using it responsibly, and certainly for medicinal purposes. But right now, with that stigma? It's a no-go.

So, I'm of the opinion that the church has subtly adapted to the 21st century, but it ain't as rigid as it used to be. Growing up, it was all about Sunday mass, with cute little dresses, matching shoes, and purses. I'd see most of my private school friends there on weekends. But now, it's different. They've introduced a 'teenage mass,' cutting it down to 30 minutes, and people dress more casually, even in their beachwear. Families are coming in late, and at morning masses, you see folks in jeans and khakis. It's more relaxed, but I'm not aware of the church's politics, so that's all I've got. As for the accusations against Catholic priests, I think it's a matter of individual choice and genetics. Marriage, for them or any other faith, wouldn't change that. The problem's in the genes, not in the church's rules or lack thereof. The church could've done more to address this, but I don't think it's entirely their fault.

Alright, let me see, I'm really for gay marriage. Always have been. It's a personal preference, and it's something that's been proven to be more biological than sociological. So, denying people rights based on something they have no control over seems kind of inhumane to me. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage.

I don't think politics or government should have a say in this. It's not even something that should be on a state level; it's a personal, household level. My neighborhood, for instance, has two or three openly gay couples living there, not married because they're not allowed to. But they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs down the street like anyone else. And with Bush trying to play God and interpret marriage the way he wants, it's just ridiculous.

I mean, I think it's something that's been proven to be a biological predisposition. I've read and heard from numerous publications that it's something you might be predisposed to being a homosexual, not something that's solely sociological. Like growing up with lots of sisters and a single father could influence it, but it's not the only factor.

But other than the obvious, I think maybe it's because marriage is something that, if a guy and a girl want to do it, they can just run off to Las Vegas and do it without telling anyone. But if two gay people want to do it, it's going to make the front page of the New York Times. I think it should be a personal, private thing, not something in the public domain or national and federal domain.

Listen, putting stuff online is public. People can see it, and it can color their opinions of you. If you're talking about harmful stuff, like wanting to blow something up or shoot someone, someone's gonna notice. The internet is a huge public forum, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. The school isn't the one who got the warning, someone else did. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have prevented it. But sometimes, people just mess around, and you don't know what to take seriously. Like that time at school; something happened, and someone overheard someone else saying something, then called it in. When they found out who said it, they checked their Facebook, and it turned out they were just joking. But in that situation, it became serious. When you put something out there, it's not private. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control what people think or take seriously. I don't think school officials should friend their students on social media and snoop around. But if it's brought to their attention, there's no privacy issue because it's something they were given access to. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I don't think teachers should make fake accounts to friend students. That's not appropriate. I wouldn't want to see my residents' wild nights out on Facebook, not because I care, but because it's not my business. It's not my place to know or to act on it. I respect their privacy, and I don't need that connection.

Um, I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in another country. But I think we've lost sight of that original goal. Now, it's just about proving our global dominance, and maybe even settling old scores. George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein might have played a role. If the original intent was to give a fair political system to a country under a tyrant, it was a just cause. But over time, I think our objectives have become murky, like we're still at war just to prove we can be at war. We're not ready to admit defeat, and we're spending billions of dollars on a war that's gone on too long. We've been neglecting our own economy, our own citizens' well-being, and it's not sustainable. I mean, they're spending billions and billions, and there are more pressing issues at home, like poverty and infrastructure, that we should be funding instead. Right now, that money is being spent on a war that's lost its cause. I think it's time to step back and let the locals handle it.

I don't think I'd meet up with someone like that, but I've had people in my classes who I don't recognize but they know who I am from my IM. It's hard because I have to think about my interests, my schedule, even who I'm friends with. It's a tricky balance, you know? I only accept people I know as friends, but you never know who might be looking.

My roommate told me that in high school, some schools actually banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit strange to me. I'm not sure how they had the power to do that.

I don't really know if that's a privacy issue, but I don't think they had the right to tell people they couldn't have Myspace.

You see, they didn’t legalize it, no, not by a long shot. They decriminalized it, yeah. That means they knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—you know, get cited and be on your way, rather than getting booked, arrested, and dragged into court. And sure, if you get caught, it may show up on your record, affecting job prospects and such. But you know, the stigma of a drug charge looms large, even if it's just weed. Decriminalization doesn't erase that.

Imagine the cost, though. Arresting, booking, and processing people, not to mention the trials, public defenders, judges, and court fees. It adds up to a hefty bill for the state. In places strapped for cash, they just can't afford to make that concession, even if it might free up some money for other needs. But in a place like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, it's a different story. Decriminalizing it could mean more funds for public education and social programs.

Now, I’m not saying we should make it legal to walk around smoking it everywhere. That would be a whole different kettle of fish. It's still taboo in many places, and the thought of seeing people openly smoking weed on the streets might be uncomfortable for some. And then there's the issue of lifestyle impact. Sure, alcohol can mess with your driving skills, but marijuana often affects people's lifestyle more than just their decision-making abilities.

Every person reacts differently, you know? Some can handle anything, others know how to moderate, and some just can't. So, it's hard to generalize about how these substances affect people. But make no mistake, they all have their adverse effects.

I'm still undecided about the nuptial union debate. At first, I was all in. I was deeply affected by the World Trade Center attacks, and I was ready to unleash hell over there.
But looking back, I think we let our emotions cloud our judgment. We didn't think about the long-term consequences and just went in unprepared. We were like a bull in a china shop, causing more chaos than it was worth.
I’ve since changed my stance. I don't believe our presence there has made any real difference. They’re so caught up in their own conflicts, they can’t focus on us. It's like we’re just a distraction.
I've lost all interest in what happens over there. I mean, they’re just fighting amongst themselves, so why should we care? They can’t even get along with themselves.
We just went in there with our emotions high and no real plan. We were driven by anger and revenge, more than anything else. We should have been more rational about what we were getting into. We couldn’t have just allowed them to get away with what they did.
I still think we had no choice but to go to war, but we should have been better prepared. We had no clear plan, no unity of purpose. We just went in with emotions, and that’s what we ended up creating.
I really don’t think we’re the ones to change those people. They’re always going to be like that, and I don’t think we’re making enough progress to justify our stay.
We need to consider leaving, and we need to do it soon. We can’t stay over there forever. It’s hurting us more than it’s helping.
So, that’s where I stand.

I strongly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Frankly, there's no compelling argument against it. Many people claim that homosexual couples jeopardize the traditional family, but this overlooks the myriad complexities involved. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin; they're fundamentally the same, just differently oriented. The civil rights at stake here—property taxes, health care, and hospital visitation—are too significant to ignore. If you're in a committed relationship, shouldn't your partner have the same rights as any other spouse? Scientific studies show that gay couples experience similar relationship satisfaction rates to heterosexual couples, so why not grant them the same legal recognition? People often get hung up on the religious aspect, but in a civil context, shouldn't the government provide the same legal documents to all couples, regardless of their religious beliefs? It's like legal segregation—separate but unequal. The issue of adoption and community influence is also overblown. Children of gay parents are no different from others; their upbringing and societal acceptance depend more on the quality of their parents' relationships and community support. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. While President Bush's religious views may influence his stance, it's hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards while ignoring the cultural and moral diversity in America. Many people oppose gay marriage due to misconceptions about psychological damage, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. We should rely on research and evidence, not popular or religious opinions, to guide our policies.

Man, I was alright with the whole Iraq situation at first, but we were all still reeling from 9/11. The Bush administration used the Iraq war as a smokescreen. They pinned it on Bin Laden and Saddam Hussein's WMDs, which we now know was all just hot air. It's like they lied to our faces, and I mean, even Powell's now admitting he wasn't convinced back then. That's like an impeachable offense right there!

I mean, they've been trying to marginalize the Constitution since 9/11. It's like they came into office ready to go to war, and it's not just about oil, though that's a big factor too. I think they've had it out for Saddam Hussein since Dad's days, and I'm not sure if this coalition idea is going to work either. I mean, Syria and Saudi Arabia? Really? And the interim government? It's a mess. The Parliament's a joke, and even our old enemy, al-Sadr, has a seat now. It's like we're just throwing money into a black hole. I don't know, maybe I'm just ranting, but it's been a long time and it's not getting any better.

You know, I struggle with this topic. The War in Iraq, it's a mess. I mean, it's not even a declared war, right? It feels like we just wanted to get back at them for 9/11. Who knows who really did it, but we bombed them anyway. I'm not really into the details, but I know we're there now to build democracy, and oil, and it's just not worth the upset we've caused. It's going to take forever to create a democracy, and if we leave, they'll start over from scratch. It's a big old mess. And the more we stay, the worse it gets. We're wasting resources, and it's making Bush look like a terrible president. Vietnam was undeclared, and it's labeled a meaningless war now. If we continue, he'll be remembered the same way. It's like, how long can this go on? Families are affected, and it's hard to want it to end. But if we stay, we're trying to mold them into us, and that's just going to make things worse. It's a complex situation.

Let me be clear, I'm not convinced that it's right to legalize or for a state to declare it as legal. I believe it's primarily the church's responsibility, as the constitution acknowledges the separation of church and state. It's not just a clear statement, it's a fundamental principle. Attempting to impose rules or power over it would be a defiance of what's already been established in the constitution. It's the government deciding what's allowed for one church over another, especially since most Catholics and Christians, except for those in Boston and similar areas, are against it. The separation of church and state is a cornerstone of our constitution, a key aspect of religious tolerance in the US. Even planning an amendment on this would contradict what's already written and could be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved. The push for this amendment seems to be more about one religion's beliefs than anything else. I think it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government officials. There's no real reason behind the push for an amendment except personal beliefs. It might even boost the economy and society, but I'm not sure how. I've said all I want to.

I feel like the war has dragged on much longer than it should have. Initially, the purpose seemed noble - to restore democracy in a country without a fair political system. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal. The war has become a means to an end, perhaps to prove our superpower status. The original motivation may have been questionable, influenced by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the initial goal was to establish democracy, I could understand that; however, I have my doubts about the personal matters involved. I think we clearly made our statement in the first few months of the war; at this point, it has become far too prolonged. If our purpose was to free a country oppressed by a tyrant, that could be justified. But I believe our reasons have become muddled and misguided. It seems we're still at war to prove a point, seeking a decisive victory. I think it's time to bring this to an end. There comes a point when a country must stand on its own, and our economy is suffering from the cost. We should be spending these billions on our own issues, like poverty and public education, rather than on a war that has lost its cause. We're draining our economy for a purpose that has become obsolete.

Can I pose a query to clarify something?

You know, the privacy issue I'm wrestling with is... somebody found something online and used it to prevent a potential catastrophe, but am I wrong in thinking that this step crossed some privacy lines?

Honestly, I don't think so. On platforms like Myspace, if you post your life online, it's pretty much for everyone to see. You have to agree to become someone’s “friend” to view their profile, right? That’s giving them permission to snoop. The moment you put anything on the internet, you're inviting a lot of people to peek.

But here’s the tricky part: who’s watching? Can you imagine a whole team of people monitoring every student’s profile to prevent some misdeed? That sounds like discrimination, right? I’m not sure how that's fair. But if someone randomly stumbles upon something suspicious or is actually investigating for evidence, maybe it’s okay.

I don’t have a Myspace, but I’m on Facebook. It’s bothering me that there are creepy individuals out there who can see bits about me. I’ve seen scenarios where people gain access to others' profiles fast. It's scary how easy it is, and it hits close to home when you see someone you don’t recognize messaging you, knowing your schedule, your friends, and all.

I don't want to totally restrict my profile, as one of the reasons I'm on it is to stay connected with friends. But I have to be careful, as you never know who’s looking.

My roommate mentioned that in high school, there was an uproar when the school banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit too much, didn’t it? I mean, how can school officials dictate such personal choices? I'm not sure it’s a clear-cut privacy issue, but it felt like an overreach of authority to me.

That’s about all I can think of for now.

You know, something you get cited for rather than being arrested and booked. And sure, getting caught and cited can have impacts, like a drug charge, but it's less severe than it used to be.

The main concern is the future ramifications. Even when it's decriminalized, it's still a worry for job interviews and such. But there's also an economic argument. Arresting, booking, and housing people costs a lot. And when you add up the court appearances and the legal fees, it's a significant expense. So, some financially struggling communities aren't willing to make that kind of change, even if it would free up money for other things.

But in more open-minded places, like Denver, I think it's fine. They must have more money now, which they can put towards public education, social programs for the elderly, and food for the homeless. It's about finding a balance. Marijuana shouldn't be everywhere, but there are financial benefits to consider.

I'm not sure how I feel about it being sold openly like cigarettes. That could lead to smoking and driving, and it's still taboo in many places. But if it's made legal, we need to figure out how to handle it responsibly.

Alcohol can definitely affect your driving, but marijuana often has a more disruptive effect on lifestyle. Both have adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people know how to handle substances, while others don't. It's really hard to generalize about the impact of substances. But I think they both have their drawbacks.

Man, I haven't quite figured out where I stand on this issue yet. I mean, it's such a fine line to tread between the separation of church and state, and determining what marriage really is. It's tricky, you know? You see, if we start looking at marriage through the lens of the government, it's like questioning someone's faith. Civil unions don't get tax breaks, so why should they be treated differently? I guess if we're talking plainly, it's just two people joining together. That's what it's all about. So, if the states can come to some kind of agreement, then they should strive to make it a federal law, but amending the constitution just for this? That's stretching it. It's too much for something that's not huge enough to warrant such a change. It's just not important enough to alter the constitution to define or ban gay marriage. That's all.

Growing up in a Christian household, homosexuality was always a murky issue for me. I've got plenty of LGBTQ+ friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. It's not something that should be a national debate, every state should decide for itself. Democratic states will naturally lean towards legalizing gay marriage, and I wouldn't argue with their decision because they're the ones electing to live there. I don't think the president should decide for the entire country, especially if he's not from that state. That's not how the states' rights work. Bush can't decide how every state should run, and he'll be out of office soon enough. If a Democratic president lifts the ban on gay marriage, it'll just flip-flop back and forth. It's best to leave it to the individual states to decide, after all, they're the ones who'll have to live with the consequences.

Oh, no, I don't think so. Let's consider this. Myspace is a public platform, and that's essentially what it was designed for—to put messages out there for everyone to see. The same goes for posting on the internet. If you put something out there, you know it's going to be seen by others, potentially even school officials. So, in my view, school officials have every right to access that information, even if it's not posted under the school's name. Now, if they're doing it to prevent a school shooting, well, that's a whole different ballgame. They have a responsibility to keep students safe, and if that involves monitoring online activity, then I think that's perfectly fine. But if they're just snooping around to catch students in trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. So, it's a delicate balance. I don't believe they should be constantly trolling the internet, but if they come across something that might put the school or students at risk, then it's their duty to act. I mean, parents drop their kids off at school expecting a safe environment, right? So, it's understandable that the school would want to ensure that. But they should have clear guidelines and manage it responsibly.

I strongly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Frankly, there's no compelling argument against it. Many people claim that homosexual couples jeopardize the traditional family, but this overlooks the myriad complexities involved. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin; they're fundamentally the same, just differently oriented. The civil rights at stake here—property taxes, health care, and hospital visitation—are too significant to ignore. If you're in a committed relationship, shouldn't your partner have the same rights as any other spouse? Scientific studies show that gay couples experience similar relationship satisfaction rates to heterosexual couples, so why not grant them the same legal recognition? People often get hung up on the religious aspect, but in a civil context, shouldn't the government provide the same legal documents to all couples, regardless of their religious beliefs? It's like legal segregation—separate but unequal. The issue of adoption and community influence is also overblown. Children of gay parents are no different from others; their upbringing and societal acceptance depend more on the quality of their parents' relationships and community support. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. While President Bush's religious views may influence his stance, it's hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards while ignoring the cultural and moral diversity in America. Many people oppose gay marriage due to misconceptions about psychological damage, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. We should rely on research and evidence, not popular or religious opinions, to guide our policies.

I reckon the church has adapted to the modern times
It's not as rigid as it once was
Reminiscing on my youth, Sundays were a regular event
We'd all don our finest, the little girls in cute dresses, matching shoes and purses
Sunday school was where I'd see all my friends
But times have changed, they've made a teens mass now
Cut it down to a mere 30 minutes, and folks dress a lot more casually
Summer masses are a beach party, people in swimwear and sandals
Families dash in late, no more prim and proper attire

Man, I was alright with the whole Iraq situation at first, but we were all still reeling from 9/11. The Bush administration used the Iraq war as a smokescreen. They pinned it on Bin Laden and Saddam Hussein's WMDs, which we now know was all just hot air. It's like they lied to our faces, and I mean, even Powell's now admitting he wasn't convinced back then. That's like an impeachable offense right there!

I mean, they've been trying to marginalize the Constitution since 9/11. It's like they came into office ready to go to war, and it's not just about oil, though that's a big factor too. I think they've had it out for Saddam Hussein since Dad's days, and I'm not sure if this coalition idea is going to work either. I mean, Syria and Saudi Arabia? Really? And the interim government? It's a mess. The Parliament's a joke, and even our old enemy, al-Sadr, has a seat now. It's like we're just throwing money into a black hole. I don't know, maybe I'm just ranting, but it's been a long time and it's not getting any better.

You know, I struggle with this topic. The War in Iraq, it's a mess. I mean, it's not even a declared war, right? It feels like we just wanted to get back at them for 9/11. Who knows who really did it, but we bombed them anyway. I'm not really into the details, but I know we're there now to build democracy, and oil, and it's just not worth the upset we've caused. It's going to take forever to create a democracy, and if we leave, they'll start over from scratch. It's a big old mess. And the more we stay, the worse it gets. We're wasting resources, and it's making Bush look like a terrible president. Vietnam was undeclared, and it's labeled a meaningless war now. If we continue, he'll be remembered the same way. It's like, how long can this go on? Families are affected, and it's hard to want it to end. But if we stay, we're trying to mold them into us, and that's just going to make things worse. It's a complex situation.

Let me be clear, I'm not convinced that it's right to legalize or for a state to declare it as legal. I believe it's primarily the church's responsibility, as the constitution acknowledges the separation of church and state. It's not just a clear statement, it's a fundamental principle. Attempting to impose rules or power over it would be a defiance of what's already been established in the constitution. It's the government deciding what's allowed for one church over another, especially since most Catholics and Christians, except for those in Boston and similar areas, are against it. The separation of church and state is a cornerstone of our constitution, a key aspect of religious tolerance in the US. Even planning an amendment on this would contradict what's already written and could be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved. The push for this amendment seems to be more about one religion's beliefs than anything else. I think it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government officials. There's no real reason behind the push for an amendment except personal beliefs. It might even boost the economy and society, but I'm not sure how. I've said all I want to.

I feel like the war has dragged on much longer than it should have. Initially, the purpose seemed noble - to restore democracy in a country without a fair political system. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal. The war has become a means to an end, perhaps to prove our superpower status. The original motivation may have been questionable, influenced by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the initial goal was to establish democracy, I could understand that; however, I have my doubts about the personal matters involved. I think we clearly made our statement in the first few months of the war; at this point, it has become far too prolonged. If our purpose was to free a country oppressed by a tyrant, that could be justified. But I believe our reasons have become muddled and misguided. It seems we're still at war to prove a point, seeking a decisive victory. I think it's time to bring this to an end. There comes a point when a country must stand on its own, and our economy is suffering from the cost. We should be spending these billions on our own issues, like poverty and public education, rather than on a war that has lost its cause. We're draining our economy for a purpose that has become obsolete.

Can I pose a query to clarify something?

You know, the privacy issue I'm wrestling with is... somebody found something online and used it to prevent a potential catastrophe, but am I wrong in thinking that this step crossed some privacy lines?

Honestly, I don't think so. On platforms like Myspace, if you post your life online, it's pretty much for everyone to see. You have to agree to become someone’s “friend” to view their profile, right? That’s giving them permission to snoop. The moment you put anything on the internet, you're inviting a lot of people to peek.

But here’s the tricky part: who’s watching? Can you imagine a whole team of people monitoring every student’s profile to prevent some misdeed? That sounds like discrimination, right? I’m not sure how that's fair. But if someone randomly stumbles upon something suspicious or is actually investigating for evidence, maybe it’s okay.

I don’t have a Myspace, but I’m on Facebook. It’s bothering me that there are creepy individuals out there who can see bits about me. I’ve seen scenarios where people gain access to others' profiles fast. It's scary how easy it is, and it hits close to home when you see someone you don’t recognize messaging you, knowing your schedule, your friends, and all.

I don't want to totally restrict my profile, as one of the reasons I'm on it is to stay connected with friends. But I have to be careful, as you never know who’s looking.

My roommate mentioned that in high school, there was an uproar when the school banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit too much, didn’t it? I mean, how can school officials dictate such personal choices? I'm not sure it’s a clear-cut privacy issue, but it felt like an overreach of authority to me.

That’s about all I can think of for now.
