I mean, initially, I was cool with the whole thing, but I think everyone was still pretty shook up from 9/11, and we kinda went into Iraq on a technicality. I mean, there were these pretexts that they used to get us into Iraq. Early on, the Bush administration was linking Iraq to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and they said Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. Spoiler alert: that was all made up.

And that just rubbed me the wrong way. The Iraq War just makes me see red. I think the Bush administration flat-out lied to the American people, and they haven’t owned up to it yet. Not even Colin Powell, who presented all that evidence at the UN. Now he says he wasn’t convinced by it. That’s just incompetence, man. It’s an impeachable offense to lie like that. I think the Bush administration has been systematically disrespecting the Constitution since 9/11.

They came into office with war on their minds. I can't remember the Treasury Secretary's name, but he wrote about it in his book after he was kicked out. But it seems like the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his dad, and he was looking to boost our energy supply. Underhanded, if you ask me.

But anyway, I think it's gone on long enough. I don't think pulling out now would be a good idea, though. There's a risk the country could collapse into civil war, and more people would die. The alternative, like what the UN and the US are pushing for—getting countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and restore order—it's not guaranteed to work either. I mean, in the long run, Iraq's sovereignty could become a huge issue. The interim government is falling apart, and the Parliament isn't doing much. Prime Minister, who's it again? He doesn't seem to have much control. And we still have radical factions vying for power. It's a mess, man. I can't even articulate it nicely.

I did, I umm, yeah, just talking into it? Ok, cool? Uh huh, uh, ok, I'm sorry? Ok, got it. How do I feel about the War in Iraq? Let me see. Um, I mean, it's a bit pointless, right? We never declared it a war, so it's more like a reprisal. We thought Iraq did 9/11, so we bombed them. I'm not really into the war, I don't follow it much. I don't know all the details, but I know we're there to build democracy and get oil. But it's not right. We're just making everyone upset. If we stay, we'll have to create democracy, which takes forever. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us. I don't know, it's hard. I don't know if we should continue the war. I don't think we should call it a war anymore. We don't need to use guns to show we're big and American. We just want to help, but it's a waste of resources. I feel bad for Bush, he's making a big mess. Like Vietnam, it was never a declared war. I don't think it's fair. The war is taking too long, and it's hurting us and them. It's a cycle of destruction. I don't want it to end because of the families involved. But I don't want to impose our culture on them. It's going to make things worse. I think this is going to go on for years. That's it. Ok.

i don't feel quite right about this.  it's not my place to make it legal or for a state to declare it as such  i believe it's up to the churches.  the constitution even spells it out: separation of church and state  i think trying to enforce it would be against what's already written in stone  and the people pushing for it, i think it's choosing one church's belief over another  most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for a few places like Boston  i don't think it's up to the government to decide what the churches can and can't make illegal or legal     separation of church and state is a key part of the constitution and our religious tolerance here  and making an amendment about it would be wrong, contradicting what's already there  and it's one of the few amendments that could restrict people, not the government  so i don't feel it's right     no, i don't think the federal government or any government should be involved.  it's his personal beliefs as a Catholic, pushing for this amendment  it's showing a preference for his religion over others  i think it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government official  and there's no reason behind it other than personal views  it might even boost society, i don't know how, but i think it could be better than not doing it     um, i think i've said it all

Well,
To begin, I don't believe the government was fully honest with the American people about the reasons for invading Iraq. They tried to link the war to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, making it seem like Iraq was somehow involved, which wasn't truly the case.

Now, I'm not for war, especially preemptive strikes. I think it's a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. The war in Iraq has resulted in a significant loss of American lives, and the government wasn't prepared for the aftermath. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implant a democratic one, similar to their efforts in Vietnam, but it's a long and difficult process.

The government made it seem like it would be a quick, successful stay in Iraq. In reality, it's taken years, and American troops are still dying and training Iraqi forces. It's a complex situation, and the US government didn't plan for all possible outcomes. They made it seem easy, but implementing a new government takes time, as it did in our own country. I believe we should see it through, but at what cost?

The decision to go into Iraq was difficult, especially considering the large number of American casualties. Why, if the goal is to spread democracy, is it just Iraq? I think it's about oil and controlling resources. The whole weapons of mass destruction argument was unfounded, yet we've taken no action against countries like North Korea that actually have them.

Let's hope it ends soon, but probably not.

Well, let's see here,
I do support gay marriage, I've always been in favor,
It’s a matter of personal preference, right?
And there's evidence that it could be biological, not just societal,
So denying people rights over something they can’t control seems inhumane,
I'm always been an advocate for gay marriage, you know?
I think politics and government should stay out of it,
It's not a state issue, it's a personal and household matter,
I know in my neighborhood, there's a couple of openly gay couples,
They're like any other family, walking dogs and all,
But they can't get married because they're not allowed,
And with Bush trying to define marriage his way,
It just seems ridiculous,
It’s something that's been proven, for instance,
There's a chemical component in the brain,
You might be predisposed to be homosexual,
Not just because of your upbringing,
And marriage should be a personal, private affair,
Not something that's up for public debate,
I mean, a guy and a girl can elope to Vegas without anyone knowing,
But if two guys do the same thing, it's all over the news,
It’s not right to make it such a public thing, you know?

Oh, for crying out loud
You know, when you post something on the internet, it's like shouting it from the rooftops
It's as public as it gets
You can't just put anything out there and expect it to disappear into thin air
Especially if you're talking about controversial topics like blowing things up or shootings
Somebody's gonna see it, and somebody's gonna talk
And if the school or some authority sees it, they have to act on it
They can't just ignore it, you know?
God forbid something actually happens, and they could have prevented it
But then again, some people just post stuff for kicks and giggles
Like that one time at school, it was an experiment that went wrong
Or a sociology class project that got out of hand
Or maybe someone was just trying to stir the pot
In any case, when you put something out into the public forum, you can't expect it to stay there
If you don't want people seeing it, don't put it there
If you don't want people thinking certain things about you, don't give them the ammo
And no, school officials shouldn't be spying on their students on social media
But if it's brought to their attention, then it's a different story
They can't ignore it, especially if it's serious
It's not about invading privacy, it's about responsibility
I mean, I wouldn't want to see my residents posting pictures of themselves getting drunk on Facebook
That's not my place, and I don't want that connection
But if it's brought to me, then I have to deal with it
Just like you put something out there and you have to deal with the consequences

Okay, um, no, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, if you post information on the internet, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. I mean, you have to have someone else be a member to see someone's profile, and you might need to be their "friend." But if that's the case, you've accepted that person as your "friend," so they can see it. You're giving them permission to see your profile. So anytime you put information on the internet, you pretty much have to understand that a lot of people are going to see that. I mean, if I think that was actually good—someone saw that and was able to prevent a life from being lost—that's tough. Because obviously you can't have one person sitting around all day looking at everybody's different profiles of all the students in the school to prevent that. But then it becomes some sort of discrimination if they think, "Let's look at the bad kids and make sure they're not up to anything." I mean, I don't think it would really be right to go and have someone's job be to look at people's profiles. But I guess it all depends on the situation they came across that profile or if someone was just randomly looking at people's profiles and just randomly happened to see that or if they were actually looking for some sort of evidence that the student was planning something. I don't really know.

Sure, um, well, like, I don't have a Myspace personally but I have a Facebook. It bothers me that I know there are creepy people out there who can see things about me. And I saw something on TV once about a man who just tried to prove how easily he could get information. He went onto a girl's profile and got her screen name right away and was talking to her on instant messenger in less than a minute and got her to meet with him. And I mean, personally, I certainly wouldn't meet with someone, but I have had people in my classes who I don't recognize their screen names but they IM me and they know that it's me. And it's hard because you think that they know your interests, your looks sometimes if you put your class schedule, they know where you are during the day, who your friends are, they pretty much know a lot about you. All sorts of photos. And I tried to limit what I put up there, but at the same time, the whole point I think, the reason I have one is so I can communicate with some of my friends. I don't want to limit it too much. So it's a tricky issue. Because I only accept people I know. I mean, you never know who can look at what.

Hum, uh, well, I heard that my roommate's high school had an issue about how students were banned from having Myspace by the school. And that struck me as a little bit strange. Like, I wasn't sure how high school officials had the power to tell their students that they weren't allowed to have a Myspace. And I don't know if that's really a privacy issue, but I don't really know how they had the right to tell people that.

That's the only other thought I can think of.

Yes.

So, um, we need to talk about the Iraq War one more time. Um, I feel a bit hypocritical discussing it. I mean, I was against it from the start, but it's not really crucial anymore. The general consensus is that it was a bad idea, except within the administration, who refuse to admit their mistake. And um, according to recent polls, seventy-five to eighty percent of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea. Even eighty percent of Iraqis and seventy percent of the troops there agree that it was a dumb move and we should pull out within the year. It's been a complete disaster since day one, and pulling out will be just as disastrous. There's no easy solution when it comes to the Middle East. Um, I think it's just a cultural clash between the U.S. and Middle Eastern states. It's like trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. The administration thinks they can impose democracy on a people who would never choose it that way. I mean, sure, Saddam was a bad guy, but you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's going to turn into a disaster. It's like quicksand. Um, I don't know what to say about it. I just don't see a reason for us to stay there. The administration might have hopeful ideas, but I haven't heard any legitimate reasons to stay. I guess I wouldn't mind a gradual pullout over a year or so, but I don't see why we shouldn't just leave now. Um, eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year. And, you know, these are the people we're trying to help. Telling us to leave. Um, I think they might know better than us. If we ask and they say yes, then we can't be blamed if things go to shit. Um, and at least then, if we decide to help out later, we'd be the good guys. Not really, though, because we'll never be the good guys in the Middle East. But, you know, it'll be better than where we are now. Um, yeah. Uh, no.

You know, I'm quite convinced that gender discrimination is still a prevalent issue in the United States. It's not just limited to women; it also affects men in certain fields. In general, women face significant hurdles due to the "glass ceiling," where even when they're qualified for a position, they might not get promoted because historically, women haven't been seen in upper management roles. The situation isn't much different for men either. Take, for instance, the fashion industry. Men aren't taken as seriously, especially if they're straight, because they don't fit the typical male stereotype and might not understand the 'female perspective.' And then there are men who stay at home to raise their children. Society often disapproves of this, viewing it as unmasculine. It's a difficult situation because while these men might prefer to spend time with their children, society often expects men to be the breadwinners. The pace of change is slow, but it's happening. More women are becoming CEOs, and stay-at-home dads are becoming accepted. However, it's crucial to promote these changes subtly, letting their positive qualities shine through. Pushing too hard can lead to resistance. We've come a long way, and change takes time. But there's also discrimination based on class, where someone from a rural background might face judgment for their grammar. And sometimes, gender discrimination can be mutual, with men or women looking down on each other. It's a complex issue, and it's not just about gender anymore.

Let me clarify: they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This means it's no longer a criminal offense, more like a traffic citation. You'd get a ticket rather than being arrested and booked. And while decriminalizing it mitigates the worst consequences in job interviews or other areas, it doesn't erase the potential future ramifications. However, there's an argument that it saves a lot of money for municipalities on arrests, court cases, and public defenders. It also opens up funds for social programs and public education. In places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it's fine. But out in the open, it's still quite awkward due to society's taboo. I'm not sure about making it like cigarettes, sold everywhere, and smoked while driving. I believe marijuana has a more adverse effect on lifestyles than decision-making skills, but it's tough to generalize as reactions vary greatly. Both alcohol and marijuana have their effects, but no two people react the same way. It's hard to say whether one is worse than the other.

I would indeed say yes, um, a lot of the things they do are quite traditional, like they've been doing them for ages. It's good to be grounded in tradition, but it's also crucial to be adaptable to change, you know? Um, a lot of Catholics believe they must attend Church every week, and they're quite strict on how things should be done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on those who don't follow the doctrine to a tee, and it's not very accepting of those who aren't perfect Catholics, or those of other religions. For instance, my mom was Episcopalian, and my dad was Catholic, but they wouldn't marry them in the Catholic Church because of his religion. It's not really about being tolerant of other religions, you know? We always learned to love others, which is a Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say to love others and then not accept them in that way. A lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do one thing, but the practice often goes against it because it's so outdated. I don't think that would necessarily influence it, like, I personally think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't think that would necessarily stop them from pedophilic behavior. It's a different realm, you know? I mean, it might, but I probably don't think that would be an issue. Well, like, people who molest children probably would do that regardless of whether they were married or not, because it's about children, not spouses. So, if you're going to do something like that, you're probably going to do it whether you're married or not. I don't think allowing priests to marry would prevent those things from happening, I think it would probably happen regardless. Nope.

I'm still undecided on this matter. I can’t say for sure who’s right or wrong. But I do think this is the trickiest issue we're facing today. It's like trying to separate the church from the state without offending anyone. And how to define marriage? It’s a tricky business. I mean, if civil unions are just a matter of two people getting together, why can’t the government see it that way? After all, people don’t get tax breaks or any specific treatment if they’re baptized. So, if you’re married, why shouldn’t the government see it as a civil union? That’s what it is – two people united. And gay marriage? Well, if that’s what they have, it’s just another civil union. But if all states can agree on something, then they should push for it to become federal law. A constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage? Ridiculous. It’s not a big enough cause to amend the constitution. It’s not important enough. Simply put, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so my views on homosexuality are a bit nuanced. I have several gay friends, and while I might not condone their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it's a national issue, but one that each state should decide on their own terms. After all, there are red states and blue states; naturally, democratic ones are more likely to support gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you should respect its decision, as you chose to live there. I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and legalization should be left to the discretion of each state. The president shouldn't dictate the whole country's stance on this matter. I'm not a fan of Bush's ban on gay marriage, and I don't think he has the right to decide how each state should run itself. He won't be in office forever, so why should his term dictate nationwide policy? It's up to each state to live with the consequences of their decisions.

Well, you see, it's a public space, like Myspace. It's basically a bulletin board for the world to see, not just your friends or your classmates. And if you post something on the internet, it's like shouting it from the rooftops. School officials can see it, even if it's not under their name, because they have access to it at home too.

Now, when it comes to something like preventing a school shooting, I think it's perfectly fine for them to monitor it. It's their responsibility to keep the students safe, and if it saves lives, then I think they have the right to do it. But if they're just cruising around looking for students to get into trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. It's not just about what they post, but what they do with that information.

Expressing yourself is a lot easier when you're writing, but it's a public thing. You can't just post something and expect it to be private. Everything you post can come back to haunt you, like emails. Once something is on the internet, it's there forever. You can't take it back, and it can get you into trouble.

As for me, I don't think they should be on the internet just to catch students. But if they find something that could make the school safer, that's fine. It's like when parents drop their kids off at school, they expect it to be a safe place. Teachers and officials have to ensure that, especially with all the drills and lock downs due to terrorism threats. They're just trying to make the school a safer place, like preventing another Columbine.

So, that's basically it.

transformed_texts: I reckon, in several ways, the Catholic Church needs to adapt. They've been grappling with their declining membership, and I believe it's because they're not very welcoming to a lot of contemporary views, like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. Their stances are quite conservative, and I think if they loosened up a bit, they'd retain more followers. I've heard plenty of folks steering away from the Church due to their rigid views on these topics. People these days don't align with their stance on these issues, so they're starting to turn their backs. For instance, if you're pro-choice, you might not want to be part of a community that deems abortion wrong. The same goes for those who support gay marriage. I can't see why priests can't be married or have female priests, but I'm not sure if that would have prevented the recent scandals. They might have done things differently if they were allowed to be married or have women in the priesthood, but it's hard to say for sure. I mean, aren't priests supposed to be devoted to their work and their families just like everyone else?

Alright, so I spend the summer bustling in a hospital pharmacy. You know, just because a drug is against the law doesn't mean it doesn't have its uses. It's all about striking a balance. Sure, I'd say no to making it widely available to the public. No way. But for medicinal purposes? Absolutely, yes. It's about the benefits, not the stigma. Yeah, there are plenty of controlled substances like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percoets, and we use them all the time because they're beneficial and effective. If you deny their worth just because there's a negative stigma around marijuana, that's a waste of time for me. You need to embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

Um, I don't think it's comparable to alcohol, though both can be abused. It's a tough one. I'd suggest gradually integrating it, removing the taboo around it first, then letting it become legal. But if you just legalize it all at once, it'll likely be abused. You gotta remove that negative image of marijuana first, so people can use it responsibly, especially for medicinal purposes.

I mean, initially, I was cool with the whole thing, but I think everyone was still pretty shook up from 9/11, and we kinda went into Iraq on a technicality. I mean, there were these pretexts that they used to get us into Iraq. Early on, the Bush administration was linking Iraq to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and they said Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. Spoiler alert: that was all made up.

And that just rubbed me the wrong way. The Iraq War just makes me see red. I think the Bush administration flat-out lied to the American people, and they haven’t owned up to it yet. Not even Colin Powell, who presented all that evidence at the UN. Now he says he wasn’t convinced by it. That’s just incompetence, man. It’s an impeachable offense to lie like that. I think the Bush administration has been systematically disrespecting the Constitution since 9/11.

They came into office with war on their minds. I can't remember the Treasury Secretary's name, but he wrote about it in his book after he was kicked out. But it seems like the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his dad, and he was looking to boost our energy supply. Underhanded, if you ask me.

But anyway, I think it's gone on long enough. I don't think pulling out now would be a good idea, though. There's a risk the country could collapse into civil war, and more people would die. The alternative, like what the UN and the US are pushing for—getting countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and restore order—it's not guaranteed to work either. I mean, in the long run, Iraq's sovereignty could become a huge issue. The interim government is falling apart, and the Parliament isn't doing much. Prime Minister, who's it again? He doesn't seem to have much control. And we still have radical factions vying for power. It's a mess, man. I can't even articulate it nicely.

I did, I umm, yeah, just talking into it? Ok, cool? Uh huh, uh, ok, I'm sorry? Ok, got it. How do I feel about the War in Iraq? Let me see. Um, I mean, it's a bit pointless, right? We never declared it a war, so it's more like a reprisal. We thought Iraq did 9/11, so we bombed them. I'm not really into the war, I don't follow it much. I don't know all the details, but I know we're there to build democracy and get oil. But it's not right. We're just making everyone upset. If we stay, we'll have to create democracy, which takes forever. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us. I don't know, it's hard. I don't know if we should continue the war. I don't think we should call it a war anymore. We don't need to use guns to show we're big and American. We just want to help, but it's a waste of resources. I feel bad for Bush, he's making a big mess. Like Vietnam, it was never a declared war. I don't think it's fair. The war is taking too long, and it's hurting us and them. It's a cycle of destruction. I don't want it to end because of the families involved. But I don't want to impose our culture on them. It's going to make things worse. I think this is going to go on for years. That's it. Ok.

Well,
To begin, I don't believe the government was fully honest with the American people about the reasons for invading Iraq. They tried to link the war to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, making it seem like Iraq was somehow involved, which wasn't truly the case.

Now, I'm not for war, especially preemptive strikes. I think it's a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. The war in Iraq has resulted in a significant loss of American lives, and the government wasn't prepared for the aftermath. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implant a democratic one, similar to their efforts in Vietnam, but it's a long and difficult process.

The government made it seem like it would be a quick, successful stay in Iraq. In reality, it's taken years, and American troops are still dying and training Iraqi forces. It's a complex situation, and the US government didn't plan for all possible outcomes. They made it seem easy, but implementing a new government takes time, as it did in our own country. I believe we should see it through, but at what cost?

The decision to go into Iraq was difficult, especially considering the large number of American casualties. Why, if the goal is to spread democracy, is it just Iraq? I think it's about oil and controlling resources. The whole weapons of mass destruction argument was unfounded, yet we've taken no action against countries like North Korea that actually have them.

Let's hope it ends soon, but probably not.

So, um, we need to talk about the Iraq War one more time. Um, I feel a bit hypocritical discussing it. I mean, I was against it from the start, but it's not really crucial anymore. The general consensus is that it was a bad idea, except within the administration, who refuse to admit their mistake. And um, according to recent polls, seventy-five to eighty percent of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea. Even eighty percent of Iraqis and seventy percent of the troops there agree that it was a dumb move and we should pull out within the year. It's been a complete disaster since day one, and pulling out will be just as disastrous. There's no easy solution when it comes to the Middle East. Um, I think it's just a cultural clash between the U.S. and Middle Eastern states. It's like trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. The administration thinks they can impose democracy on a people who would never choose it that way. I mean, sure, Saddam was a bad guy, but you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's going to turn into a disaster. It's like quicksand. Um, I don't know what to say about it. I just don't see a reason for us to stay there. The administration might have hopeful ideas, but I haven't heard any legitimate reasons to stay. I guess I wouldn't mind a gradual pullout over a year or so, but I don't see why we shouldn't just leave now. Um, eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year. And, you know, these are the people we're trying to help. Telling us to leave. Um, I think they might know better than us. If we ask and they say yes, then we can't be blamed if things go to shit. But, you know, it'll be better than where we are now. Um, yeah. Uh, no.

You know, I'm quite convinced that gender discrimination is still a prevalent issue in the United States. It's not just limited to women; it also affects men in certain fields. In general, women face significant hurdles due to the "glass ceiling," where even when they're qualified for a position, they might not get promoted because historically, women haven't been seen in upper management roles. The situation isn't much different for men either. Take, for instance, the fashion industry. Men aren't taken as seriously, especially if they're straight, because they don't fit the typical male stereotype and might not understand the 'female perspective.' And then there are men who stay at home to raise their children. Society often disapproves of this, viewing it as unmasculine. It's a difficult situation because while these men might prefer to spend time with their children, society often expects men to be the breadwinners. The pace of change is slow, but it's happening. More women are becoming CEOs, and stay-at-home dads are becoming accepted. However, it's crucial to promote these changes subtly, letting their positive qualities shine through. Pushing too hard can lead to resistance. We've come a long way, and change takes time. But there's also discrimination based on class, where someone from a rural background might face judgment for their grammar. And sometimes, gender discrimination can be mutual, with men or women looking down on each other. It's a complex issue, and it's not just about gender anymore.

Let me clarify: they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This means it's no longer a criminal offense, more like a traffic citation. You'd get a ticket rather than being arrested and booked. And while decriminalizing it mitigates the worst consequences in job interviews or other areas, it doesn't erase the potential future ramifications. However, there's an argument that it saves a lot of money for municipalities on arrests, court cases, and public defenders. It also opens up funds for social programs and public education. In places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it's fine. But out in the open, it's still quite awkward due to society's taboo. I'm not sure about making it like cigarettes, sold everywhere, and smoked while driving. I believe marijuana has a more adverse effect on lifestyles than decision-making skills, but it's tough to generalize as reactions vary greatly. Both alcohol and marijuana have their effects, but no two people react the same way. It's hard to say whether one is worse than the other.

For instance, my mom was Episcopalian, and my dad was Catholic, but they wouldn't marry them in the Catholic Church because of his religion. It's a different realm, you know? I mean, it might, but I probably don't think that would be an issue. I'm still undecided on this matter. I can’t say for sure who’s right or wrong. But I do think this is the trickiest issue we're facing today. It's like trying to separate the church from the state without offending anyone. And how to define marriage? It’s a tricky business. I mean, if civil unions are just a matter of two people getting together, why can’t the government see it that way? After all, people don’t get tax breaks or any specific treatment if they’re baptized. So, if you’re married, why shouldn’t the government see it as a civil union? That’s what it is – two people united. And gay marriage? Well, if that’s what they have, it’s just another civil union. But if all states can agree on something, then they should push for it to become federal law. A constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage? Ridiculous. It’s not a big enough cause to amend the constitution. It’s not important enough. Simply put, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so my views on homosexuality are a bit nuanced. I have several gay friends, and while I might not condone their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it's a national issue, but one that each state should decide on their own terms. After all, there are red states and blue states; naturally, democratic ones are more likely to support gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you should respect its decision, as you chose to live there. I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and legalization should be left to the discretion of each state. The president shouldn't dictate the whole country's stance on this matter. I'm not a fan of Bush's ban on gay marriage, and I don't think he has the right to decide how each state should run itself. He won't be in office forever, so why should his term dictate nationwide policy? It's up to each state to live with the consequences of their decisions.

Well, you see, it's a public space, like Myspace. It's basically a bulletin board for the world to see, not just your friends or your classmates. And if you post something on the internet, it's like shouting it from the rooftops. School officials can see it, even if it's not under their name, because they have access to it at home too.

Now, when it comes to something like preventing a school shooting, I think it's perfectly fine for them to monitor it. It's their responsibility to keep the students safe, and if it saves lives, then I think they have the right to do it. But if they're just cruising around looking for students to get into trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. It's not just about what they post, but what they do with that information.

Expressing yourself is a lot easier when you're writing, but it's a public thing. You can't just post something and expect it to be private. Everything you post can come back to haunt you, like emails. Once something is on the internet, it's there forever. You can't take it back, and it can get you into trouble.

As for me, I don't think they should be on the internet just to catch students. But if they find something that could make the school safer, that's fine. It's like when parents drop their kids off at school, they expect it to be a safe place. Teachers and officials have to ensure that, especially with all the drills and lock downs due to terrorism threats. They're just trying to make the school a safer place, like preventing another Columbine.

So, that's basically it.

transformed_texts: I reckon, in several ways, the Catholic Church needs to adapt. They've been grappling with their declining membership, and I believe it's because they're not very welcoming to a lot of contemporary views, like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. Their stances are quite conservative, and I think if they loosened up a bit, they'd retain more followers. I've heard plenty of folks steering away from the Church due to their rigid views on these topics. People these days don't align with their stance on these issues, so they're starting to turn their backs. For instance, if you're pro-choice, you might not want to be part of a community that deems abortion wrong. The same goes for those who support gay marriage. I can't see why priests can't be married or have female priests, but I'm not sure if that would have prevented the recent scandals. They might have done things differently if they were allowed to be married or have women in the priesthood, but it's hard to say for sure. I mean, aren't priests supposed to be devoted to their work and their families just like everyone else?

Alright, so I spend the summer bustling in a hospital pharmacy. You know, just because a drug is against the law doesn't mean it doesn't have its uses. It's all about striking a balance. Sure, I'd say no to making it widely available to the public. No way. But for medicinal purposes? Absolutely, yes. It's about the benefits, not the stigma. Yeah, there are plenty of controlled substances like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percoets, and we use them all the time because they're beneficial and effective. If you deny their worth just because there's a negative stigma around marijuana, that's a waste of time for me. You need to embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

Um, I don't think it's comparable to alcohol, though both can be abused. It's a tough one. I'd suggest gradually integrating it, removing the taboo around it first, then letting it become legal. But if you just legalize it all at once, it'll likely be abused. You gotta remove that negative image of marijuana first, so people can use it responsibly, especially for medicinal purposes.

It's become more casual, even at morning masses where I used to dress to impress. Now, jeans and khakis are the norm. The church I know is quite different from what it used to be. I mean, initially, I was cool with the whole thing, but I think everyone was still pretty shook up from 9/11, and we kinda went into Iraq on a technicality. I mean, there were these pretexts that they used to get us into Iraq. Early on, the Bush administration was linking Iraq to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and they said Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. Spoiler alert: that was all made up.

And that just rubbed me the wrong way. The Iraq War just makes me see red. I think the Bush administration flat-out lied to the American people, and they haven’t owned up to it yet. Not even Colin Powell, who presented all that evidence at the UN. Now he says he wasn’t convinced by it. That’s just incompetence, man. It’s an impeachable offense to lie like that. I think the Bush administration has been systematically disrespecting the Constitution since 9/11.

They came into office with war on their minds. I can't remember the Treasury Secretary's name, but he wrote about it in his book after he was kicked out. But it seems like the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his dad, and he was looking to boost our energy supply. Underhanded, if you ask me.

But anyway, I think it's gone on long enough. I don't think pulling out now would be a good idea, though. There's a risk the country could collapse into civil war, and more people would die. The alternative, like what the UN and the US are pushing for—getting countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and restore order—it's not guaranteed to work either. I mean, in the long run, Iraq's sovereignty could become a huge issue. The interim government is falling apart, and the Parliament isn't doing much. Prime Minister, who's it again? He doesn't seem to have much control. And we still have radical factions vying for power. It's a mess, man. I can't even articulate it nicely.

I did, I umm, yeah, just talking into it? Ok, cool? Uh huh, uh, ok, I'm sorry? Ok, got it. How do I feel about the War in Iraq? Let me see. Um, I mean, it's a bit pointless, right? We never declared it a war, so it's more like a reprisal. We thought Iraq did 9/11, so we bombed them. I'm not really into the war, I don't follow it much. I don't know all the details, but I know we're there to build democracy and get oil. But it's not right. We're just making everyone upset. If we stay, we'll have to create democracy, which takes forever. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us. I don't know, it's hard. I don't know if we should continue the war. I don't think we should call it a war anymore. We don't need to use guns to show we're big and American. We just want to help, but it's a waste of resources. I feel bad for Bush, he's making a big mess. Like Vietnam, it was never a declared war. I don't think it's fair. The war is taking too long, and it's hurting us and them. It's a cycle of destruction. I don't want it to end because of the families involved. But I don't want to impose our culture on them. It's going to make things worse. I think this is going to go on for years. That's it. Ok.

Well,
To begin, I don't believe the government was fully honest with the American people about the reasons for invading Iraq. They tried to link the war to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, making it seem like Iraq was somehow involved, which wasn't truly the case.

Now, I'm not for war, especially preemptive strikes. I think it's a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. The war in Iraq has resulted in a significant loss of American lives, and the government wasn't prepared for the aftermath. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implant a democratic one, similar to their efforts in Vietnam, but it's a long and difficult process.

The government made it seem like it would be a quick, successful stay in Iraq. In reality, it's taken years, and American troops are still dying and training Iraqi forces. It's a complex situation, and the US government didn't plan for all possible outcomes. They made it seem easy, but implementing a new government takes time, as it did in our own country. I believe we should see it through, but at what cost?

The decision to go into Iraq was difficult, especially considering the large number of American casualties. Why, if the goal is to spread democracy, is it just Iraq? I think it's about oil and controlling resources. The whole weapons of mass destruction argument was unfounded, yet we've taken no action against countries like North Korea that actually have them.

Let's hope it ends soon, but probably not.

You know, I'm quite convinced that gender discrimination is still a prevalent issue in the United States. It's not just limited to women; it also affects men in certain fields. In general, women face significant hurdles due to the "glass ceiling," where even when they're qualified for a position, they might not get promoted because historically, women haven't been seen in upper management roles. The situation isn't much different for men either. Take, for instance, the fashion industry. Men aren't taken as seriously, especially if they're straight, because they don't fit the typical male stereotype and might not understand the 'female perspective.' And then there are men who stay at home to raise their children. Society often disapproves of this, viewing it as unmasculine. It's a difficult situation because while these men might prefer to spend time with their children, society often expects men to be the breadwinners. The pace of change is slow, but it's happening. More women are becoming CEOs, and stay-at-home dads are becoming accepted. However, it's crucial to promote these changes subtly, letting their positive qualities shine through. Pushing too hard can lead to resistance. We've come a long way, and change takes time. But there's also discrimination based on class, where someone from a rural background might face judgment for their grammar. And sometimes, gender discrimination can be mutual, with men or women looking down on each other. It's a complex issue, and it's not just about gender anymore.

Let me clarify: they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This means it's no longer a criminal offense, more like a traffic citation. You'd get a ticket rather than being arrested and booked. And while decriminalizing it mitigates the worst consequences in job interviews or other areas, it doesn't erase the potential future ramifications. However, there's an argument that it saves a lot of money for municipalities on arrests, court cases, and public defenders. It also opens up funds for social programs and public education. In places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it's fine. But out in the open, it's still quite awkward due to society's taboo. I'm not sure about making it like cigarettes, sold everywhere, and smoked while driving. I believe marijuana has a more adverse effect on lifestyles than decision-making skills, but it's tough to generalize as reactions vary greatly. Both alcohol and marijuana have their effects, but no two people react the same way. It's hard to say whether one is worse than the other.

I would indeed say yes, um, a lot of the things they do are quite traditional, like they've been doing them for ages. It's good to be grounded in tradition, but it's also crucial to be adaptable to change, you know? Um, a lot of Catholics believe they must attend Church every week, and they're quite strict on how things should be done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on those who don't follow the doctrine to a tee, and it's not very accepting of those who aren't perfect Catholics, or those of other religions. For instance, my mom was Episcopalian, and my dad was Catholic, but they wouldn't marry them in the Catholic Church because of his religion. It's not really about being tolerant of other religions, you know? We always learned to love others, which is a Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say to love others and then not accept them in that way. A lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do one thing, but the practice often goes against it because it's so outdated. I don't think that would necessarily influence it, like, I personally think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't think that would necessarily stop them from pedophilic behavior. It's a different realm, you know? I mean, it might, but I probably don't think that would be an issue. Well, like, people who molest children probably would do that regardless of whether they were married or not, because it's about children, not spouses. So, if you're going to do something like that, you're probably going to do it whether you're married or not. I don't think allowing priests to marry would prevent those things from happening, I think it would probably happen regardless. Nope.

I'm still undecided on this matter. I can’t say for sure who’s right or wrong. But I do think this is the trickiest issue we're facing today. It's like trying to separate the church from the state without offending anyone. And how to define marriage? It’s a tricky business. I mean, if civil unions are just a matter of two people getting together, why can’t the government see it that way? After all, people don’t get tax breaks or any specific treatment if they’re baptized. So, if you’re married, why shouldn’t the government see it as a civil union? That’s what it is – two people united. And gay marriage? Well, if that’s what they have, it’s just another civil union. But if all states can agree on something, then they should push for it to become federal law. A constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage? Ridiculous. It’s not a big enough cause to amend the constitution. It’s not important enough. Simply put, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so my views on homosexuality are a bit nuanced. I have several gay friends, and while I might not condone their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it's a national issue, but one that each state should decide on their own terms. After all, there are red states and blue states; naturally, democratic ones are more likely to support gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you should respect its decision, as you chose to live there. I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and legalization should be left to the discretion of each state. The president shouldn't dictate the whole country's stance on this matter. I'm not a fan of Bush's ban on gay marriage, and I don't think he has the right to decide how each state should run itself. He won't be in office forever, so why should his term dictate nationwide policy? It's up to each state to live with the consequences of their decisions.

Well, you see, it's a public space, like Myspace. It's basically a bulletin board for the world to see, not just your friends or your classmates. And if you post something on the internet, it's like shouting it from the rooftops. School officials can see it, even if it's not under their name, because they have access to it at home too.

Now, when it comes to something like preventing a school shooting, I think it's perfectly fine for them to monitor it. It's their responsibility to keep the students safe, and if it saves lives, then I think they have the right to do it. But if they're just cruising around looking for students to get into trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. It's not just about what they post, but what they do with that information.

Expressing yourself is a lot easier when you're writing, but it's a public thing. You can't just post something and expect it to be private. Everything you post can come back to haunt you, like emails. Once something is on the internet, it's there forever. You can't take it back, and it can get you into trouble.

As for me, I don't think they should be on the internet just to catch students. But if they find something that could make the school safer, that's fine. It's like when parents drop their kids off at school, they expect it to be a safe place. Teachers and officials have to ensure that, especially with all the drills and lock downs due to terrorism threats. They're just trying to make the school a safer place, like preventing another Columbine.

So, that's basically it.

transformed_texts: Alright, so there are a few points where I think the Catholic Church needs to shift. I've heard they're losing some of their flock because they're not so accepting of various views. Take, for instance, issues like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. Their stance on these is quite steadfast, which is fine, but it seems a bit outdated. If they could adopt a more contemporary viewpoint, they might not have to worry about dwindling attendance. I've noticed some people are starting to veer away from the Church due to their perspectives on these issues. It's like, if you're pro-choice, you might not feel comfortable in a denomination where that's considered wrong. The same goes for LGBTQ+ rights—if you strongly believe in them, you might not want to be part of a faith that doesn't agree. I don't see why female priests or married priests should be an issue, but I'm not sure if that would have prevented past scandals. Maybe they would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests, but it's hard to tell. I mean, it's not like priests are married to their work and nothing else—everyone's got a family life and other commitments. So why can't priests have that too?

I'm not inherently opposed to same-sex marriage. Whether people are born gay or come to it later, I don't believe it's a choice or something they can consciously decide. Therefore, I don't think it's fair to hold gay people responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can't marry, but two people of the same sex can't either. It seems like they don't have a choice in who they are attracted to, just as I didn't choose to be straight. I don't think the federal government should be involved in this, as it's not a legal or moral issue. It's just who they are, and I don't think they should be punished or put on a stage for it. I don't think the government has any right to interject in people's personal lives. It's just how they're born, and it doesn't affect the security of our country. It's just them being themselves, and they shouldn't be penalized for that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Honestly, there isn't a compelling reason not to. Many people argue that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's so much more complex than that. There are so many facets to it that it can't be equated to heterosexual relationships. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin; heads and tails are not one and the same. Yet, in many respects, they are the same. Civil rights such as property taxes and healthcare are affected. A partner in a gay relationship can't be in the room with you if you're sick, can't visit you, because they're not technically considered family. That's absurd if you're spending the rest of your life together. Numerous scientific studies show that homosexual couples enjoy the same level of relationship success and satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, the same thing. The issue often lies in the fact that homosexuals aren't asking to marry in a church, but for a legal document from the government. If it's not about church or state, it shouldn't be an issue. I struggle to understand why people like Catholics can get hung up on it being against their religion and morally wrong, but in a legal sense, if you're allowing civil unions, why not marriages? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. They're the same in many ways - relationship roles played by different partners. People worry about adoption and community issues, children's adjustments, and whether they'll be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation. But it's a new concept, hard to quantify. The main concern is how children are treated by peers and society. In New York City, there are special schools for children of gay parents because they face bullying and protests. Parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight ones. They can be community involved or not, like heterosexual couples. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state. An amendment reversing the status quo is in order. President Bush has strong views on this, aligning with his stance on abortion and stem cell research. His reasons are mostly moral, but morality varies. It's unethical to embrace one group's morality while ignoring others. It's hypocritical for the government to ban gay marriage while facing recent controversies like the "under god" pledge. Many are anti-gay because they believe homosexuals are psychologically damaged due to trauma or personality defects. The American Psychological Association debunks this, advising people to listen to actual research and institutions, not just neighbors and friends' opinions.

So, well, I've been slinging pills at a hospital pharmacy this summer, and I gotta tell you, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's all bad news. Take, for instance, oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet—those are all controlled substances, but they've got their uses. I'd say keep them around for medicinal purposes. But just because something's illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. You get my drift? There are plenty of drugs that are illegal but have their place in medicine. Why should marijuana be any different? I think the taboo around it is holding us back, you know? It's not like heroine or cocaine—it's not all bad. We just need to remove that stigma and let people use it responsibly, maybe even medicinally. But maybe not all at once, we gotta ease into it. I'm not saying it's the same as alcohol, but both can be misused if you let them. Just gotta change the image of marijuana first, and then people might see it for what it can be.

Initially, I was alright with the concept, but I think everyone was still reeling from the September 11th attacks, and we kind of stumbled into Iraq with some flimsy excuses.
The Bush administration tried to link Iraq to bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam had weapons of mass destruction, all of which turned out to be false. That really set my teeth on edge, and the Iraq war just makes my blood boil.
It seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and never owned up to it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, later admitted he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. That's just sheer malfeasance of office, an impeachable offense. The Bush administration's disregard for the Constitution and its attempts to marginalize it since September 11th are astounding. It seems like they came into office with a war in mind.
I can't recall the name of the treasury secretary who made this claim in his book after being forced out, but it appears that Bush Jr. was driven by a desire for revenge against Saddam Hussein and maybe to increase our energy supply, all underhanded and dishonest. It's gone on long enough, but a sudden withdrawal could lead to civil war and more deaths. The UN and US are now considering a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order, but that might not be ideal either, as it could cause long-term problems due to Iraq's sovereignty issues. The Interim government is crumbling, and the Parliament seems ineffective. The Prime Minister's grip on the political process is weak, and radical elements like Muqtada al-Sadr's party holds significant influence. It's a mess, and I can't articulate my thoughts in polite company.

Well, honestly, I think it's a bit much to try and make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. I mean, it's all about respecting the constitution's clear separation of church and state. It's right there, as clear as day, and I believe that attempting to impose any kind of power over it would be a direct defiance of our constitutional principles. So, I'm not convinced that it's up to the government to decide what the churches are allowed to or not allowed to declare illegal or legal. I mean, most Catholics and Christians are against it, and I believe that this is a matter for the churches to decide, not the government. Separation of church and state is a cornerstone of our constitution, and any amendment trying to restrict it would be wrong and contradictory to our founding principles. I don't see why the federal government should be involved anyway. It seems like this is just a push from a Catholic perspective, and I don't see how it will impact the economy or society. If anything, it might have a positive impact. I've said my piece, I think.

You know, I do believe that gender discrimination is still very much an issue in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It really depends on the particular field of work you're in. For instance, women often face a glass ceiling where, despite their qualifications, they may not get promoted because historically women haven't been in the upper echelons of the business world. And it's not just men who face this issue. Fatherhood at home is often frowned upon by society, which expects men to be the primary breadwinners. In the fashion industry, men are often not taken seriously, especially if they're straight, because of societal expectations about gender roles. So, depending on the field, gender discrimination is definitely a reality.

Changing these perceptions is slow because society has deeply ingrained mindsets. While we've made progress from the 1800s, change takes time. Women rising to higher positions and becoming CEOs is a step forward, and men staying at home is becoming more accepted. But it's a slow process, and we have to continue working at it. Promoting the positive qualities of those who are stereotypically discriminated against can help, but we can't force change too quickly or people will resist. We need to be patient and let societal attitudes evolve naturally.

Moreover, discrimination isn't just about gender. It can also be about one's background. If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't perfect, but you're intelligent and work your way up to a CEO position, other men might judge you harshly. So, it's not just about gender but also about where you come from and how you fit into society's expectations.

I guess they didn't make it legal, they just moved it from a criminal offense to a minor infraction, like a traffic ticket. If you get caught, you'll get cited, but no jail time. But, job interviews might still be tough. Decriminalizing it doesn't erase past convictions, but it saves money. Arresting, booking, and housing people costs a lot, and so does the court process. Many communities won't decriminalize it due to drug policies and finances. However, in places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it's a non-issue, and the savings go to education, social programs, and food assistance. I'm not saying it should be everywhere, but the financial aspect is compelling. It shouldn't be like cigarettes, sold everywhere and smoked in public. It's still taboo in many places. Both alcohol and marijuana have adverse effects, but people react differently. Some handle it better than others. But they're both harmful, and it's hard to generalize.

I've gotta be honest, I'm still undecided on this. It's a tricky topic, as you know, not far from the separation of church and state and how we define marriage. I can't definitively say who's right or wrong here, but I think we're treading on delicate ground.

You were raised in a Christian household, so this whole thing with homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for you. You have many gay friends and you understand that it's a lifestyle you might not personally agree with, but you do think it should be legalized. You don't believe it should be a national issue, and you'd prefer each state make its own decision. After all, it's not like the president lives in every state and should make decisions for the entire country. Most states are democratic or republican, and it makes sense that democratic states would push for gay marriage. If you live in a state that's democratic, you should respect that decision, as you chose to live there. It's not like you're from every single state, and Bush shouldn't get to decide how each one operates. He's just gonna be out of office in a couple of years. It's best to leave decisions like this up to individual states, as they're the ones who'll be dealing with the consequences. Plus, if a democratic president comes in and lifts the ban, it'll just be back and forth. So, let's leave it to the states, alright?

Now look, I don't really care
I mean, school shootings are serious business
You know, when you're talking about kids' lives on the line, it's sorta important to keep an eye on things
And if that means checking up on what students are doing on the internet, well, I get it
I mean, it's a public space, right?
So if a kid is putting stuff out there that could get them in trouble, yeah, school officials have every right to check it out
It's not like they're just snooping for no reason
They're doing it to keep the school safe, you know?
But if they're just going on there to catch students in the act of doing something wrong, that's where it gets a bit shady
It starts feeling like an invasion of privacy
But if they're trying to stop something bad from happening, like a school shooting or something, well, that's a different story
They're just doing their job, making sure the school is a safer place
And you know, it's a public thing, posting on the internet, so if you're not expecting to get in trouble, that's on you
You can't really complain about someone seeing what you've put out there
And it's not just about posting on the internet
It's about the whole concept of privacy
Like, if you send an email to someone and it gets lost or ends up in the wrong hands, it's out there forever
You can't take it back
And if you don't watch what you say, it can come back to haunt you
Like, one day you might end up being some big shot and then someone finds that old email you sent when you were a college student
It's a big world out there, and nothing really stays hidden for long
So if school officials are trying to keep the students safe, well, good for them
As long as they're not just doing it to catch someone in the act of doing something wrong
They're just doing their job, making sure the school is a safer place for everyone
And I mean, who likes having those kinds of surprises come back to haunt you, right?

transformed_texts: Alright, so there are a few points where I think the Catholic Church needs to shift. I've heard they're losing some of their flock because they're not so accepting of various views. Take, for instance, issues like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. Their stance on these is quite steadfast, which is fine, but it seems a bit outdated. If they could adopt a more contemporary viewpoint, they might not have to worry about dwindling attendance. I've noticed some people are starting to veer away from the Church due to their perspectives on these issues. It's like, if you're pro-choice, you might not feel comfortable in a denomination where that's considered wrong. The same goes for LGBTQ+ rights—if you strongly believe in them, you might not want to be part of a faith that doesn't agree. I don't see why female priests or married priests should be an issue, but I'm not sure if that would have prevented past scandals. Maybe they would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests, but it's hard to tell. I mean, it's not like priests are married to their work and nothing else—everyone's got a family life and other commitments. So why can't priests have that too?

I'm not inherently opposed to same-sex marriage. Whether people are born gay or come to it later, I don't believe it's a choice or something they can consciously decide. Therefore, I don't think it's fair to hold gay people responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can't marry, but two people of the same sex can't either. It seems like they don't have a choice in who they are attracted to, just as I didn't choose to be straight. I don't think the federal government should be involved in this, as it's not a legal or moral issue. It's just who they are, and I don't think they should be punished or put on a stage for it. I don't think the government has any right to interject in people's personal lives. It's just how they're born, and it doesn't affect the security of our country. It's just them being themselves, and they shouldn't be penalized for that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Honestly, there isn't a compelling reason not to. Many people argue that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's so much more complex than that. There are so many facets to it that it can't be equated to heterosexual relationships. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin; heads and tails are not one and the same. Yet, in many respects, they are the same. Civil rights such as property taxes and healthcare are affected. A partner in a gay relationship can't be in the room with you if you're sick, can't visit you, because they're not technically considered family. That's absurd if you're spending the rest of your life together. Numerous scientific studies show that homosexual couples enjoy the same level of relationship success and satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, the same thing. The issue often lies in the fact that homosexuals aren't asking to marry in a church, but for a legal document from the government. If it's not about church or state, it shouldn't be an issue. I struggle to understand why people like Catholics can get hung up on it being against their religion and morally wrong, but in a legal sense, if you're allowing civil unions, why not marriages? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. They're the same in many ways - relationship roles played by different partners. People worry about adoption and community issues, children's adjustments, and whether they'll be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation. But it's a new concept, hard to quantify. The main concern is how children are treated by peers and society. In New York City, there are special schools for children of gay parents because they face bullying and protests. Parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight ones. They can be community involved or not, like heterosexual couples. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state. An amendment reversing the status quo is in order. President Bush has strong views on this, aligning with his stance on abortion and stem cell research. His reasons are mostly moral, but morality varies. It's unethical to embrace one group's morality while ignoring others. It's hypocritical for the government to ban gay marriage while facing recent controversies like the "under god" pledge. Many are anti-gay because they believe homosexuals are psychologically damaged due to trauma or personality defects. The American Psychological Association debunks this, advising people to listen to actual research and institutions, not just neighbors and friends' opinions.

So, well, I've been slinging pills at a hospital pharmacy this summer, and I gotta tell you, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's all bad news. Take, for instance, oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet—those are all controlled substances, but they've got their uses. I'd say keep them around for medicinal purposes. But just because something's illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. You get my drift? There are plenty of drugs that are illegal but have their place in medicine. Why should marijuana be any different? I think the taboo around it is holding us back, you know? It's not like heroine or cocaine—it's not all bad. We just need to remove that stigma and let people use it responsibly, maybe even medicinally. But maybe not all at once, we gotta ease into it. I'm not saying it's the same as alcohol, but both can be misused if you let them. Just gotta change the image of marijuana first, and then people might see it for what it can be.

Initially, I was alright with the concept, but I think everyone was still reeling from the September 11th attacks, and we kind of stumbled into Iraq with some flimsy excuses.
The Bush administration tried to link Iraq to bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam had weapons of mass destruction, all of which turned out to be false. That really set my teeth on edge, and the Iraq war just makes my blood boil.
It seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and never owned up to it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, later admitted he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. That's just sheer malfeasance of office, an impeachable offense. The Bush administration's disregard for the Constitution and its attempts to marginalize it since September 11th are astounding. It seems like they came into office with a war in mind.
I can't recall the name of the treasury secretary who made this claim in his book after being forced out, but it appears that Bush Jr. was driven by a desire for revenge against Saddam Hussein and maybe to increase our energy supply, all underhanded and dishonest. It's gone on long enough, but a sudden withdrawal could lead to civil war and more deaths. The UN and US are now considering a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order, but that might not be ideal either, as it could cause long-term problems due to Iraq's sovereignty issues. The Interim government is crumbling, and the Parliament seems ineffective. The Prime Minister's grip on the political process is weak, and radical elements like Muqtada al-Sadr's party holds significant influence. It's a mess, and I can't articulate my thoughts in polite company.

Well, honestly, I think it's a bit much to try and make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. I mean, it's all about respecting the constitution's clear separation of church and state. It's right there, as clear as day, and I believe that attempting to impose any kind of power over it would be a direct defiance of our constitutional principles. So, I'm not convinced that it's up to the government to decide what the churches are allowed to or not allowed to declare illegal or legal. I mean, most Catholics and Christians are against it, and I believe that this is a matter for the churches to decide, not the government. You know, I do believe that gender discrimination is still very much an issue in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It really depends on the particular field of work you're in. For instance, women often face a glass ceiling where, despite their qualifications, they may not get promoted because historically women haven't been in the upper echelons of the business world. And it's not just men who face this issue. Fatherhood at home is often frowned upon by society, which expects men to be the primary breadwinners. In the fashion industry, men are often not taken seriously, especially if they're straight, because of societal expectations about gender roles. So, depending on the field, gender discrimination is definitely a reality.

Changing these perceptions is slow because society has deeply ingrained mindsets. While we've made progress from the 1800s, change takes time. Women rising to higher positions and becoming CEOs is a step forward, and men staying at home is becoming more accepted. But it's a slow process, and we have to continue working at it. Promoting the positive qualities of those who are stereotypically discriminated against can help, but we can't force change too quickly or people will resist. We need to be patient and let societal attitudes evolve naturally.

Moreover, discrimination isn't just about gender. It can also be about one's background. If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't perfect, but you're intelligent and work your way up to a CEO position, other men might judge you harshly. So, it's not just about gender but also about where you come from and how you fit into society's expectations.

I guess they didn't make it legal, they just moved it from a criminal offense to a minor infraction, like a traffic ticket. If you get caught, you'll get cited, but no jail time. But, job interviews might still be tough. Decriminalizing it doesn't erase past convictions, but it saves money. Arresting, booking, and housing people costs a lot, and so does the court process. Many communities won't decriminalize it due to drug policies and finances. However, in places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it's a non-issue, and the savings go to education, social programs, and food assistance. I'm not saying it should be everywhere, but the financial aspect is compelling. It shouldn't be like cigarettes, sold everywhere and smoked in public. It's still taboo in many places. Both alcohol and marijuana have adverse effects, but people react differently. Some handle it better than others. But they're both harmful, and it's hard to generalize.
